title: ACT Test Basics & Overview
content:
Understanding the ACT Test structure, scoring system, timing strategies, and question types is essential before diving into specific content. The ACT consists of four required sections—English, Math, Reading, and Science—plus an optional Writing section. This lesson will give you a complete overview of the test format, teach you how scores work, and provide strategic insights to help you maximize your performance on test day.

1. Test Structure and Format

The ACT is a standardized test used by colleges for admissions decisions. Unlike the SAT, the ACT tests more straightforward knowledge and has a Science section. The test is divided into four required sections and one optional section, with a total testing time of about 3 hours (or 3.5 hours with Writing).

English Section: 45 Minutes, 75 Questions

The English section tests grammar, punctuation, sentence structure, and rhetorical skills across five passages. You'll have approximately 45 seconds per question. Questions test conventions of standard English (grammar and usage), production of writing (strategy and organization), and knowledge of language (style and tone). This section appears first on the test, so starting strong is crucial for building confidence.

Math Section: 60 Minutes, 60 Questions

The Math section covers pre-algebra, elementary algebra, intermediate algebra, coordinate geometry, plane geometry, and trigonometry. You have one minute per question on average. A reference sheet with basic formulas is provided, but memorizing key formulas will save time. Calculators are permitted (and highly recommended) for this entire section.

Reading Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Reading section includes four passages: Prose Fiction/Literary Narrative, Social Science, Humanities, and Natural Science. Each passage has 10 questions. You'll have about 8 minutes and 45 seconds per passage, so time management is critical. Questions test your ability to determine main ideas, locate details, understand sequences, make comparisons, comprehend cause-effect relationships, determine word meaning, and analyze author's voice and method.

Science Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Science section tests interpretation, analysis, evaluation, reasoning, and problem-solving skills through data representation, research summaries, and conflicting viewpoints passages. Don't worry—you don't need advanced science knowledge! The section primarily tests your ability to read graphs, charts, and tables, and apply scientific reasoning. Most students find this section challenging due to the pace (about 53 seconds per question).

2. Scoring System and What Scores Mean

Understanding how the ACT is scored helps you set realistic goals and track your progress. The ACT uses a scaled scoring system from 1-36, and there's no penalty for wrong answers, so you should always guess if you're running out of time.

How Scores Are Calculated

Each section (English, Math, Reading, Science) receives a scaled score from 1-36 based on the number of questions you answer correctly (your raw score). These four section scores are then averaged to create your Composite Score, which is the most important number for college admissions. The composite is rounded to the nearest whole number—for example, if your four section scores are 28, 30, 26, and 32, your composite is (28+30+26+32)/4 = 29.

What's a Good Score?

The national average composite score is around 20-21. A score of 24 puts you in approximately the 75th percentile, meaning you scored higher than 75% of test-takers. Competitive colleges typically want scores above 27, while highly selective schools (Ivy League, top liberal arts colleges) generally expect 32-36. However, "good" depends on your target schools—research the average ACT scores for admitted students at colleges you're interested in.

Subscores and STEM Score

In addition to section scores, you'll receive subscores (1-18 scale) for specific skill areas like "Production of Writing" in English or "Integrating Essential Skills" in Math. You'll also see a STEM score, which averages your Math and Science scores. While colleges primarily focus on your composite and individual section scores, subscores can help identify specific areas for improvement.

Superscoring

Many colleges practice superscoring, which means they take your highest section scores across multiple test dates and recalculate a new composite. For example, if you score English 28, Math 30, Reading 25, Science 27 on Test 1, then English 26, Math 32, Reading 28, Science 26 on Test 2, your superscore would combine the best from each: 28, 32, 28, 27 = composite 28.75, rounded to 29. Check whether your target colleges superscore—this policy encourages retaking the ACT to improve individual sections.

3. General Test-Taking Strategies

Success on the ACT requires more than content knowledge—you need effective time management, strategic guessing, and stress management skills. These universal strategies apply across all four sections.

Always Answer Every Question

The ACT has no guessing penalty—wrong answers don't count against you. This means you should NEVER leave a question blank. If you're running out of time, quickly bubble in an answer for every remaining question. Statistically, random guessing gives you about a 20-25% chance of being correct, which is better than 0%!

Pace Yourself and Use a Watch

Time pressure is one of the ACT's biggest challenges. Wear a watch (analog watches are best since digital devices aren't allowed) and set checkpoints. For example, in Reading, you should finish passage 1 by minute 8, passage 2 by minute 17, passage 3 by minute 26, and passage 4 by minute 35. Don't spend too long on any single question—if you're stuck after 30-45 seconds, make your best guess, circle it in the test booklet, and move on. You can return if time permits.

Answer Easy Questions First

Not all questions are created equal. Some are straightforward, while others require complex reasoning. Within each section, scan for "quick points"—questions you can answer confidently in 20-30 seconds. Rack up these easy points first, then tackle harder questions with your remaining time. This strategy maximizes your score even if time runs out.

Process of Elimination

When you're unsure of the correct answer, use process of elimination. Cross out answers you know are wrong in your test booklet, then guess among remaining choices. Eliminating even one wrong answer improves your odds from 20% to 25% (for 4-choice questions) or 25% to 33% (for 3-choice questions). Often you can eliminate 2-3 choices, giving you a strong chance of guessing correctly.

4. Test Day Preparation and Logistics

Your performance on test day depends not only on preparation but also on practical considerations like what to bring, how to manage stress, and what to expect at the testing center. Being well-prepared logistically helps you focus entirely on the test itself.

What to Bring

Mandatory items: your admission ticket (printed from your ACT account) and an acceptable photo ID (school ID, driver's license, or passport). Recommended items: several sharpened No. 2 pencils with erasers, an approved calculator with fresh batteries, a watch (not a smartwatch), snacks and water for breaks, and layered clothing in case the room is too hot or cold. Do NOT bring: cell phones, smartwatches, prohibited calculators, reference materials, or scratch paper (you can use the test booklet).

Night Before and Morning Of

The night before: review a few key formulas or grammar rules, but don't cram—it's more important to get 8 hours of sleep. Pack your backpack with everything you'll need. Set multiple alarms. The morning of: eat a substantial, protein-rich breakfast (avoid sugary foods that cause energy crashes). Arrive at the test center by 7:45 AM for an 8:00 AM start—latecomers aren't admitted. Use the bathroom before testing begins, as breaks are limited.

Managing Test Anxiety

Feeling nervous is normal, but excessive test anxiety can hurt your performance. Practice deep breathing techniques: inhale slowly for 4 counts, hold for 4 counts, exhale for 4 counts. During the test, if you feel overwhelmed, close your eyes for 10 seconds, take a deep breath, and refocus. Remember: you can retake the ACT—this one test doesn't define you. Confidence comes from preparation, so thorough practice with realistic timed tests is your best defense against anxiety.

After the Test

Scores are typically released 2-8 weeks after your test date (check your ACT account for the exact release date). You can send your scores to colleges for free on test day (list up to 4 schools), or pay later to send additional score reports. Many students take the ACT 2-3 times to improve their composite score—each attempt gives you new experience and insights. Review your score report carefully to identify weak areas, then create a targeted study plan for your next attempt.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The ACT has four sections: English (45 min, 75 Q), Math (60 min, 60 Q), Reading (35 min, 40 Q), Science (35 min, 40 Q)
  • ✓Scores range from 1-36 per section; your Composite is the average of all four sections
  • ✓There's no guessing penalty—ALWAYS answer every question, even if you have to guess
  • ✓Time management is crucial: use a watch, set checkpoints, and don't spend too long on any question
  • ✓Many colleges superscore—taking the ACT multiple times can improve your composite
  • ✓Test day essentials: admission ticket, photo ID, No. 2 pencils, approved calculator, watch

subject: math
title: Areas, Volumes & Triangles
content:
Geometry questions involving areas, volumes, and triangles appear on every ACT Math test, accounting for approximately 15-20% of all questions. Success on these problems requires memorizing key formulas and knowing when to apply specific triangle rules like Pythagorean theorem and special right triangle ratios.

1. Area Formulas for Common Shapes

  • You MUST memorize these area formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT:
    • Triangle: A = ½bh (where b = base, h = height)
    • Rectangle: A = lw (where l = length, w = width)
    • Square: A = s² (where s = side length)
    • Parallelogram: A = bh (base times height, NOT side lengths)
    • Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h (average of the two bases times height)
    • Circle: A = πr² (where r = radius)
    • Kite: A = ½d₁d₂ (half the product of the diagonals)
  • Common mistakes to avoid:
    • For parallelograms, use the HEIGHT (perpendicular distance), not the slanted side length
    • For circles, make sure you have the radius, not the diameter (if given diameter, divide by 2)
    • For triangles, the height must be perpendicular to the base
  • Perimeter formulas you should know:
    • Rectangle: P = 2l + 2w
    • Square: P = 4s
    • Circle (circumference): C = 2πr or C = πd

2. Volume Formulas and Unit Conversions

  • Essential volume formulas to memorize:
    • Rectangular Prism (box): V = lwh
    • Cube: V = s³
    • Right Cylinder: V = πr²h
    • Any 3D shape: V = Bh (where B = area of base, h = height)
  • Surface area formulas (less common but important):
    • Rectangular Prism: SA = 2lw + 2lh + 2wh
    • Cube: SA = 6s²
  • CRITICAL: Unit conversions—The ACT frequently tests these, and students make costly mistakes:
    • Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume
    • 1 yard = 3 feet
    • 1 foot = 12 inches
    • 1 square yard = 9 square feet (not 3!)
    • 1 square foot = 144 square inches (not 12!)
    • 1 cubic yard = 27 cubic feet (not 3!)
    • 1 cubic foot = 1,728 cubic inches (not 12!)
  • Why you must convert FIRST:
    • Example: A field is 136 yards × 93 yards. To find area in square feet:
    • ✓ CORRECT: Convert to feet first: (136 × 3) × (93 × 3) = 408 × 279 = 113,832 ft²
    • ✗ WRONG: Calculate area then convert: 136 × 93 = 12,648, then × 9 = wrong answer!

3. Right Triangles and Pythagorean Theorem

  • The Pythagorean theorem applies ONLY to right triangles:
    • a² + b² = c²
    • Where a and b are the legs (the two shorter sides)
    • c is the hypotenuse (the longest side, opposite the right angle)
  • Pythagorean triples—memorize these to save time:
    • 3-4-5 triangle: If you see sides of 3 and 4, the hypotenuse is 5
    • 5-12-13 triangle: If you see sides of 5 and 12, the hypotenuse is 13
    • These can be scaled up: 6-8-10, 9-12-15, 10-24-26, etc.
    • If you recognize a Pythagorean triple, you can skip the calculation entirely
  • When to use Pythagorean theorem:
    • Finding the third side of a right triangle when you know two sides
    • Finding distances in coordinate geometry problems
    • Solving problems with rectangles (diagonals create right triangles)
    • Working with circles and tangent lines

4. Special Right Triangles (30-60-90 and 45-45-90)

  • 45-45-90 triangle (also called a right isosceles triangle):
    • Side ratio: x : x : x√2
    • The two legs are equal (both length x)
    • The hypotenuse is x√2 (one leg times √2)
    • If the leg is 5, the hypotenuse is 5√2
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, each leg is 10/√2 = 5√2
  • 30-60-90 triangle:
    • Side ratio: x : x√3 : 2x
    • Short leg (opposite 30°): x
    • Long leg (opposite 60°): x√3
    • Hypotenuse (opposite 90°): 2x
    • KEY RULE: The short leg is always half the hypotenuse
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, the short leg is 5, and the long leg is 5√3
  • How to recognize special right triangles:
    • Look for angle measurements (45°, 30°, 60°)
    • Look for the phrase "right isosceles triangle" (45-45-90)
    • Look for equilateral triangles split in half (creates 30-60-90)
    • If you see √2 or √3 in the answer choices, it's likely a special right triangle
  • When to use special right triangles instead of Pythagorean theorem:
    • When you see the special angles (30°, 45°, 60°)
    • When the answer choices contain √2 or √3
    • Special triangles are FASTER than using a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Geometry Problems

  • Draw and label diagrams
    • If no diagram is provided, draw one yourself
    • Label all given measurements directly on the diagram
    • Mark right angles with a small square
    • Write formulas next to the shapes as you work
  • Look for Pythagorean triples first
    • Before using a² + b² = c², check if the sides are a Pythagorean triple
    • Common ones: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, and their multiples
    • This saves time and prevents calculation errors
  • Use substitution for complex problems
    • If a problem uses variables (like "a field is l feet by w feet"), pick simple numbers
    • Example: Let l = 4 and w = 3, then solve with those specific values
    • This makes algebraic area/volume problems much easier to visualize
  • Convert units before calculating
    • NEVER calculate area in yards and then convert to square feet
    • ALWAYS convert the length and width first, then calculate
    • Write out the conversion as a separate step to avoid mistakes
  • Memorize formulas NOW, not the night before
    • Make flashcards for all area and volume formulas
    • Practice drawing and labeling 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 triangles from memory
    • Review Pythagorean triples until you can recognize them instantly

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Memorize all area and volume formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT, and you must know them cold to save time
  • ✓Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume (1 square yard = 9 square feet, NOT 3)
  • ✓Recognize Pythagorean triples (3-4-5, 5-12-13) and special right triangles (45-45-90 ratio x:x:x√2, 30-60-90 ratio x:x√3:2x) to solve problems instantly
  • ✓For Pythagorean theorem, remember a² + b² = c² only works for right triangles, where c is always the hypotenuse (longest side)

subject: math
title: Lines
content:
Lines and linear functions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, testing your ability to calculate slope, write equations, and use coordinate geometry formulas. Mastering the different forms of linear equations and understanding parallel/perpendicular relationships is essential for scoring well on these questions.

1. Slope and Its Properties

  • Slope formula for any two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):
    • Slope = (y₁ - y₂) / (x₁ - x₂) = rise / run
    • Rise = change in y-coordinates
    • Run = change in x-coordinates
  • Understanding slope values:
    • Positive slope: Line goes up and to the right
    • Negative slope: Line goes down and to the right
    • Higher slope: Steeper line
    • Lower slope: Flatter line
    • Zero slope: Horizontal line
    • Undefined slope: Vertical line
  • Parallel lines: Same slope
    • If line A has slope 3, any line parallel to it also has slope 3
    • Parallel lines never intersect
  • Perpendicular lines: Slopes are negative reciprocals
    • To find the negative reciprocal: flip the fraction and change the sign
    • If line A has slope 2/3, a perpendicular line has slope -3/2
    • If line A has slope 4, a perpendicular line has slope -1/4
    • If line A has slope -5, a perpendicular line has slope 1/5
    • Perpendicular lines intersect at 90 degrees

2. Slope-Intercept Form (y = mx + b)

  • The most common and useful form of a linear equation:
    • y = mx + b
    • m = slope (steepness of the line)
    • b = y-intercept (where the line crosses the y-axis)
  • Reading information from the equation:
    • Example: y = 3x - 5 has slope 3 and y-intercept -5
    • Example: y = -2x + 7 has slope -2 and y-intercept 7
    • Example: y = (1/2)x + 4 has slope 1/2 and y-intercept 4
  • Reading information from a graph:
    • Find the y-intercept: where the line crosses the y-axis
    • Find the slope: pick two points and calculate rise/run
    • Or count: "up 2, right 1" means slope = 2/1 = 2
  • When to use slope-intercept form:
    • When you know the slope and y-intercept
    • When you need to quickly identify slope or y-intercept from an equation
    • When graphing a line

3. Point-Slope Form and Standard Form

  • Point-slope form: Use when you know a point and the slope
    • y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)
    • (x₁, y₁) is a point on the line
    • m is the slope
    • After plugging in values, solve for y to convert to slope-intercept form
  • Alternative method: Plug point into y = mx + b
    • If you know the slope m, write: y = mx + b
    • Plug in the (x, y) values of a point on the line
    • Solve for b to find the y-intercept
    • This often feels more intuitive than point-slope form
  • Standard form: Less common but sometimes useful
    • Ax + By = C
    • A, B, and C are constants (usually integers)
    • To find slope from standard form: slope = -A/B
    • To find y-intercept: set x = 0 and solve for y
    • To find x-intercept: set y = 0 and solve for x
    • Usually easier to convert to slope-intercept form first

4. Midpoint and Distance Formulas

  • Midpoint formula: Finds the point exactly halfway between two points
    • Midpoint = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)
    • Average the x-coordinates, average the y-coordinates
    • Example: Midpoint of (2, 5) and (8, 13) = ((2+8)/2, (5+13)/2) = (5, 9)
  • Distance formula: Finds the straight-line distance between two points
    • Distance = √[(x₁ - x₂)² + (y₁ - y₂)²]
    • This is the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates
    • (x₁ - x₂) is the horizontal distance
    • (y₁ - y₂) is the vertical distance
    • Square both, add them, then take the square root
  • Relationship between distance and Pythagorean theorem:
    • The distance formula IS the Pythagorean theorem
    • The two points form a right triangle with legs (x₁ - x₂) and (y₁ - y₂)
    • The distance is the hypotenuse
    • Sometimes it's easier to draw the triangle and use a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Line Questions

  • Always convert to y = mx + b when possible
    • Slope-intercept form is the easiest to work with
    • If given standard form, solve for y immediately
    • If given point-slope form, distribute and solve for y
  • For perpendicular lines, flip and negate the slope
    • Perpendicular slope = -1 / (original slope)
    • If slope is 2, perpendicular is -1/2
    • If slope is -3/4, perpendicular is 4/3
  • Use substitution to verify equations
    • If given a point and asked which equation represents the line, plug the point into each answer choice
    • The correct equation will make the point satisfy the equation
    • This can be faster than calculating slope and y-intercept
  • Draw quick sketches for visual problems
    • If given two points, plot them quickly on scratch paper
    • Visualize the slope (is it positive or negative? steep or flat?)
    • This helps catch sign errors and eliminate wrong answers
  • Memorize the formulas
    • Slope formula, midpoint formula, and distance formula must be memorized
    • They are NOT provided on the ACT
    • Practice writing them from memory until automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Parallel lines have the same slope, perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes (flip fraction and change sign)
  • ✓Always convert equations to y = mx + b form when possible—it makes finding slope and y-intercept immediate
  • ✓Memorize: slope = (y₁-y₂)/(x₁-x₂), midpoint = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2), distance = √[(x₁-x₂)² + (y₁-y₂)²]
  • ✓The distance formula is just the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates—sometimes it's easier to draw the right triangle

subject: math
title: Arcs and Sectors
content:
Arcs and sectors appear occasionally on the ACT Math test, usually 1-2 questions per test. These problems test your understanding of how parts of a circle relate to the whole circle using proportional reasoning with central angles.

1. Understanding Arcs

  • An arc is a portion of a circle's circumference
    • Think of it as a "slice" of the circle's edge
    • Arcs are measured in two ways: degree measure or arc length
  • Degree measure of an arc:
    • Equal to the measure of the central angle that intercepts it
    • A central angle is an angle whose vertex is at the center of the circle
    • Example: If the central angle is 90°, the arc measures 90°
  • Arc length (the actual distance along the curve):
    • Arc length is a portion of the total circumference
    • Use the proportion: arc length / circumference = angle / 360°
  • Arc length formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Arc Length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • 2πr = circumference of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (same formula):
    • Arc Length / Circumference = θ / 360°
    • This proportion shows: arc is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
    • Useful when you need to solve for the angle or radius

2. Understanding Sectors

  • A sector is a "slice" of a circle (like a pizza slice)
    • Bounded by two radii and an arc
    • Sectors have area, just like the whole circle has area
  • Sector area formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Sector Area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • πr² = area of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (proportion):
    • Sector Area / Circle Area = θ / 360°
    • This shows: sector is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
  • Key pattern to recognize:
    • Arc length uses circumference (2πr)
    • Sector area uses circle area (πr²)
    • Both use the same proportion: (θ/360°)

3. Solving Arc and Sector Problems

  • Step-by-step approach for arc length:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circumference: 2πr
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
  • Step-by-step approach for sector area:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circle area: πr²
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
  • Working backwards (finding angle or radius):
    • If given arc length and radius, solve for θ
    • If given sector area and angle, solve for r
    • Use algebra to isolate the unknown variable
  • Common question types:
    • Given angle and radius, find arc length or sector area
    • Given arc length and radius, find the central angle
    • Given sector area and angle, find the radius
    • Finding the difference between two arcs or sectors

4. Test-Taking Tips for Arcs and Sectors

  • Think in terms of proportions
    • The key insight: the arc/sector is a fraction of the whole circle
    • That fraction equals the central angle divided by 360°
    • Example: A 90° angle means 90/360 = 1/4 of the circle
  • Don't confuse arc length with sector area
    • Arc length is distance (1-dimensional) - uses circumference
    • Sector area is space (2-dimensional) - uses circle area
    • Read the question carefully to determine which one is asked
  • Memorize the formulas now
    • Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • These are NOT provided on the test
  • Use the proportion setup for complex problems
    • Arc/Circumference = Angle/360° is easier to manipulate algebraically
    • Especially useful when solving for the angle or radius
    • Cross-multiply to solve
  • Simplify the fraction θ/360° early
    • 90/360 = 1/4, 120/360 = 1/3, 180/360 = 1/2
    • This makes calculations much simpler
    • Example: (90/360) × 2π(12) = (1/4) × 24π = 6π

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr and Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²—these formulas are NOT provided on the ACT
  • ✓The central angle determines what fraction of the circle you have: a 90° angle = 1/4 of the circle
  • ✓Arc length is 1-dimensional (uses circumference 2πr), sector area is 2-dimensional (uses circle area πr²)
  • ✓Think proportionally: arc/circumference = sector/circle = angle/360°—this relationship solves all arc and sector problems

subject: reading
title: Reading Section Fundamentals
content:
The ACT Reading section presents unique challenges that require mastering passage comprehension, time management strategies, critical analysis skills, and evidence-based reasoning. With only 35 minutes to read four passages and answer 40 questions, you must develop efficient reading techniques that balance speed with accuracy.

This lesson provides a comprehensive overview of the Reading section structure, explains what skills are tested, introduces the four passage types you'll encounter, and outlines proven strategies for maximizing your score on this fast-paced section.

1. Understanding the Reading Section Format

The ACT Reading section is the third section of the test and consists of four passages with ten questions each. You have exactly 35 minutes to complete all 40 questions, which means approximately 8 minutes and 45 seconds per passage including both reading time and question-answering time.

Understanding the structure and format of this section is essential for developing an effective test-taking strategy.

Section Timing and Question Distribution

  • 40 questions: . Each passage is approximately 750-900 words long and accompanied by exactly 10 questions. Unlike some standardized tests where passages vary in difficulty, all four ACT Reading passages are designed to be roughly equivalent in challenge level
  • However, individual students may find certain passage types easier based on their interests and background knowledge. The strict time constraint—just over 8.5 minutes per passage—makes the Reading section one of the most time-pressured parts of the ACT. Most students report that finishing all four passages is their biggest challenge.

Passage Order and Organization

  • Humanities: (third), and
  • Natural Science: (fourth). However, you are NOT required to complete the passages in this order. Strategic test-takers often rearrange the order to tackle their strongest passage types first, building confidence and banking time for more challenging passages later. Each passage is clearly labeled with its type, author information
  • sometimes a brief italicized introduction that provides context. Questions are numbered consecutively from 1-40 across all four passages (not 1-10 for each passage), so passage one has questions 1-10, passage two has questions 11-20, and so on.

Question Format and Answer Choices

  • four answer options: (A, B, C, D). Unlike the ACT English section which has three-choice questions
  • Reading questions always have four choices. Each question has exactly one correct answer, and there is
  • no penalty for guessing: —wrong answers do not subtract from your score. Questions appear to the right of the passage (or below it in the online format)
  • you can refer back to the passage as many times as needed. Most questions are passage-based, meaning you must find evidence in the text to support your answer. A few questions may ask about vocabulary in context or require you to make reasonable inferences based on textual clues.

Scoring and Raw-to-Scale Conversion

Your Reading section score is based on the number of questions you answer correctly, called your raw score. This raw score (0-40) is then converted to a scaled score from 1-36 using a conversion table that varies slightly from test to test to account for minor difficulty differences.

Generally, missing 2-3 questions still allows you to achieve a score in the 33-35 range, while missing 6-8 questions typically results in a score around 28-30. The conversion is designed so that a scaled score of 36 requires a perfect or near-perfect raw score (39-40 correct), while a scaled score of 20 (roughly average) corresponds to answering about 23-26 questions correctly.

Because the scoring curve is relatively generous at the top end, even high-achieving students can afford to miss a few questions and still receive excellent scores.

Example: Section Breakdown

Passage 1 (Prose Fiction): Questions 1-10 | ~8:45 minutes
Passage 2 (Social Science): Questions 11-20 | ~8:45 minutes
Passage 3 (Humanities): Questions 21-30 | ~8:45 minutes
Passage 4 (Natural Science): Questions 31-40 | ~8:45 minutes

Total: 40 questions in 35 minutes = approximately 52.5 seconds per question, but you must account for reading time as well, which is why the per-passage timing works better as a guide.

2. The Four Passage Types Explained

Each ACT Reading section contains exactly four passages, each representing a different content area. Understanding the characteristics of each passage type helps you know what to expect and allows you to develop specialized strategies for each category.

While the question types remain similar across all passages, the content, writing style, and focus differ significantly.

Prose Fiction and Literary Narrative

  • Prose Fiction/Literary Narrative: passage is always the first passage and features excerpts from short stories, novels, memoirs, or personal essays. These passages focus on
  • literary devices: . You'll need to understand character motivations, identify tone and mood, track plot developments, and interpret figurative language. Questions often ask about a character's emotions, the narrator's perspective, or the significance of specific events. Literary passages can be challenging because they require careful attention to nuance, subtext
  • implied meanings rather than just explicit facts. To succeed with fiction passages, pay attention to dialogue, character interactions, descriptive details, and shifts in tone or perspective.

Social Science

  • Social Science: passage appears second and covers topics from anthropology, archaeology, biography, business, economics, education, geography, history, political science, psychology, and sociology. These passages present
  • theories: in an informative, expository style. Questions typically test your ability to identify main ideas, understand supporting details, recognize cause-and-effect relationships, and follow the author's argument or analysis
  • Social Science passages tend to be more straightforward than fiction because they explicitly state facts and conclusions rather than implying them. However, they may contain dense information that requires careful tracking of multiple concepts, names, dates, or statistics. Strong annotation and note-taking strategies are particularly useful for these passages.

Humanities

  • Humanities: passage is third and includes content related to architecture, art, dance, ethics, film, language, literary criticism, music, philosophy, radio, television, and theater. These passages often discuss
  • critical analysis of creative works: . The writing style falls somewhere between Literary Narrative and Social Science—more personal and opinion-based than pure exposition but more analytical than storytelling
  • Questions may ask you to identify the author's perspective on an artist or movement, understand historical context, or recognize how the author supports their claims about cultural significance. Humanities passages sometimes include the author's personal reflections or evaluative judgments, so pay attention to distinguishing between objective facts and subjective opinions.

Natural Science

  • Natural Science: passage appears fourth and covers topics from anatomy, astronomy, biology, botany, chemistry, ecology, geology, medicine, meteorology, microbiology, natural history, physiology, physics, technology, and zoology. These passages explain
  • technological innovations: . The writing is typically expository and informative, similar to what you'd find in a science textbook or popular science magazine. Questions test whether you understand scientific processes, can identify cause-and-effect relationships, comprehend technical vocabulary in context
  • follow the logic of scientific explanations. Don't worry if you're not familiar with the specific scientific topic—all necessary information is provided in the passage. However, Natural Science passages can be challenging due to complex terminology, detailed descriptions of processes, and abstract concepts that require visualization.

Example: Passage Type Characteristics Prose Fiction: Focus on character emotions, narrative perspective, and literary themes. Look for "The narrator feels..." or "The passage suggests that the character..." Social Science: Focus on factual information, historical context, and analytical arguments

Look for "According to the passage..." or "The author indicates that..." Humanities: Focus on artistic significance, cultural analysis, and the author's perspective. Look for "The author believes..." or "The passage describes the artist's work as..." Natural Science: Focus on scientific processes, technical explanations, and cause-effect relationships

Look for "The passage explains that..." or "According to the research described..."

3. Core Skills Tested in the Reading Section

The ACT Reading section assesses three main categories of reading comprehension skills: Key Ideas and Details, Craft and Structure, and Integration of Knowledge and Ideas. Understanding which skills are being tested helps you approach questions more strategically and develop targeted improvement strategies.

Key Ideas and Details (55-60% of questions)

  • identify cause-effect relationships: . Questions might ask: "What is the main idea of the passage?", "According to the passage, what caused X to happen?", "The author indicates that...", or "Which of the following statements about X is supported by the passage?" These questions require close reading and the ability to distinguish between major themes and supporting details
  • When answering Key Ideas questions, always refer back to the passage—don't rely on memory or outside knowledge. The correct answer will have direct textual support, even if the question requires you to paraphrase or synthesize information from multiple sentences.

Craft and Structure (25-30% of questions)

  • rhetorical strategies: . You might encounter questions like: "As it is used in line 42, the word 'revolutionary' most nearly means...", "The author's tone in the third paragraph can best be described as...", "The primary purpose of the first paragraph is to...", or "From whose perspective is the passage told?" To answer these questions successfully, pay attention not just to what the author says but how they say it
  • Consider the connotations of specific word choices, the emotional effect of descriptive language, the organizational structure of paragraphs, and the overall rhetorical approach the author takes to convey their message.

Integration of Knowledge and Ideas (13-18% of questions)

  • draw conclusions: . Questions might ask: "Which of the following claims is best supported by evidence in the passage?", "The passage suggests that...", "It can reasonably be inferred that...", or "The author would most likely agree with which statement?" These questions require you to go beyond literal comprehension and think critically about implications, assumptions
  • logical connections. When the passage presents two texts (which happens occasionally), Integration questions may ask you to compare and contrast the authors' perspectives or synthesize information from both passages. Strong critical thinking skills and the ability to distinguish between what the passage explicitly states versus what it implies are essential for these questions.

Reading Comprehension vs. Reading Speed

  • reading efficiency: . Unlike untimed reading assignments where you can reread multiple times and think deeply about every sentence
  • the ACT requires you to balance thorough understanding with time constraints. The most successful students develop
  • active reading strategies: that allow them to extract essential information quickly while still retaining enough detail to answer questions accurately. This means learning to identify what's important (main ideas, key supporting details, author's purpose) versus what's less critical (minor examples, tangential descriptions) during your first read-through
  • With practice, you can improve both your reading speed and comprehension simultaneously by training yourself to recognize patterns in passage structure and question types.

Example: Question Type Distribution

In a typical Reading section:
- 22-24 questions test Key Ideas and Details (main ideas, supporting details, sequences, cause-effect)
- 10-12 questions test Craft and Structure (vocabulary, author's purpose, tone, point of view)
- 5-7 questions test Integration of Knowledge and Ideas (inferences, arguments, conclusions)

Knowing this distribution helps you anticipate what skills you'll need to apply most frequently and where to focus your practice efforts.

4. Building a Foundation for Success

Mastering the ACT Reading section requires more than just understanding the format and question types—you need to develop systematic strategies, efficient reading habits, and test-taking discipline. This section introduces foundational concepts that will support your development as a strategic ACT reader.

Developing Active Reading Techniques

  • Active reading: means engaging with the text purposefully rather than passively absorbing words. On the ACT, this involves
  • annotation: (underlining key phrases, circling important names or dates, making brief margin notes)
  • prediction: (anticipating what information might be tested), and
  • summarization: (mentally paraphrasing each paragraph's main point as you read). Active reading keeps your mind focused and helps you retain information better than passive reading
  • Even simple techniques like underlining topic sentences or putting brackets around important examples can significantly improve your ability to locate information when answering questions. However, avoid over-annotating—excessive marking can be just as ineffective as no annotation at all. Focus on highlighting only the most essential information.

Understanding the Relationship Between Passages and Questions

  • passage-based comprehension: which means every correct answer must be supported by evidence in the text. Questions generally follow the
  • chronological order: of the passage—questions 1-3 relate to the beginning, questions 4-7 to the middle, and questions 8-10 to the end. However, some questions (particularly main idea or author's purpose questions) require you to consider the entire passage
  • Understanding this relationship helps you work more efficiently: when you see a question about a specific detail, you know approximately where in the passage to look based on the question number. Questions also frequently include
  • line references: (e.g., "In lines 45-48...") or
  • paragraph references: (e.g., "The third paragraph primarily serves to...") to guide you to the relevant section.

Recognizing Wrong Answer Patterns

  • wrong answer traps: is just as important as identifying correct answers. The ACT frequently uses several types of incorrect answer choices:
  • too extreme: (using absolute language like "always" or "never" when the passage is more nuanced)
  • distortion: (twisting information from the passage in a way that changes its meaning)
  • out of scope: (bringing in outside information or addressing topics not discussed in the passage)
  • opposite: (stating the reverse of what the passage says), and
  • partially correct: (including some accurate information but also containing a critical error)
  • Learning to identify these patterns allows you to wrong answers more quickly and confidently, even when you're not 100% certain which answer is correct.

Creating a Personal Strategy and Improving Through Practice

  • personalized approaches: based on their strengths, weaknesses, and natural reading preferences. Some students prefer to skim the passage quickly first, then read questions and return to find answers
  • Others read carefully the first time, annotating heavily, then answer questions from memory before checking the passage. Still others read questions first to know what to look for, then read the passage with those questions in mind. The key is to experiment with different strategies during practice and identify what allows you to maximize both
  • speed: . Improvement comes from consistent practice with official ACT materials, timed practice to build stamina and pacing skills
  • careful review of both correct and incorrect answers to understand the reasoning behind each question. Track your progress by passage type to identify patterns in your performance.
  • Step 1:: Take a diagnostic practice test to establish your baseline score and identify which passage types or question types are most challenging.
  • Step 2:: Experiment with different reading approaches (skim-first, read-carefully, questions-first) on individual passages to see which feels most natural and effective.
  • Step 3:: Practice your chosen strategy on timed passages, gradually building speed while maintaining accuracy.
  • Step 4:: Review every practice question—both ones you got right and wrong—to understand the reasoning and reinforce patterns.
  • Step 5:: Take periodic full-length practice tests to monitor improvement and ensure your strategy works under realistic testing conditions.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The Reading section has 35 minutes for 4 passages and 40 questions—approximately 8:45 per passage including reading time
  • ✓The four passage types always appear in the same order: Prose Fiction, Social Science, Humanities, Natural Science
  • ✓Each passage contains exactly 10 questions, all multiple-choice with four answer options
  • ✓There is no penalty for wrong answers—always guess if you're running out of time
  • ✓Most questions (55-60%) test Key Ideas and Details like main ideas and supporting details
  • ✓Craft and Structure questions (25-30%) test vocabulary in context, author's purpose, and tone
  • ✓Integration questions (13-18%) require making inferences and drawing conclusions from the passage
  • ✓Active reading strategies (annotation, prediction, summarization) improve comprehension and retention
  • ✓Questions generally follow the chronological order of the passage, making it easier to locate relevant information
  • ✓Every correct answer must be directly supported by evidence in the passage—never rely on outside knowledge

subject: reading
title: Topic 1.1 - 7 Core Principles for ACT Reading
content:
The ACT Reading section tests your ability to apply seven core principles that separate high-scoring students from those who struggle. Master these principles to dramatically improve both speed and accuracy.

1. Every Answer Must Be Supported by the Passage

The most fundamental rule: every correct answer must have direct textual support.

The ACT only cares what the passage says—not what you know. If a passage claims something factually wrong, answer based on the passage. Outside knowledge is irrelevant—only passage evidence matters.

Example 1: Evidence-Based Answering

Question: "The author's primary purpose in discussing the artist's early work is to..."

Wrong approach: "I remember this artist's early work was revolutionary..." (relying on outside knowledge)

Right approach: Find where the passage discusses early work. Read exactly what it says about the purpose. Match your answer to the passage evidence only.

2. Use Process of Elimination

Crossing out wrong answers is often faster than finding the right answer directly.

Mark clearly wrong answers with an X. Narrow to 2-3 choices before deep analysis. Compare remaining choices directly.

Common Wrong Answer Types

Too extreme: Uses "always," "never," "only" when passage is nuanced.

Opposite: Says the reverse of what passage states.

Out of scope: Mentions topics passage doesn't discuss.

Distortion: Twists passage meaning slightly.

Example 2: Eliminating Wrong Answers

Passage: "Some scientists believe climate change may contribute to more frequent hurricanes."

Question: "According to the passage, the relationship between climate change and hurricanes is..."

❌ "Climate change always causes more hurricanes" (too extreme—passage says "may contribute")

❌ "Scientists have proven the connection" (opposite—passage says "believe," not "proven")

❌ "Rising ocean temperatures increase hurricane strength" (out of scope—passage doesn't mention ocean temperatures)

✓ "Climate change is thought by some to potentially increase hurricane frequency" (matches passage exactly)

3. Read Actively, Not Passively

Active reading means engaging with the text, not just scanning words.

Active Reading Techniques

Ask "Why did the author include this?" as you read. Note main idea of each paragraph mentally. Track author's tone (positive, negative, neutral). Underline key claims or transitions.

4. Answer What's Asked, Not What You Think

Many students answer the question they expect instead of the actual question.

Reread the question stem before selecting an answer. Check: "Does this answer what was asked?" Watch for: "primarily," "best," "most," "EXCEPT".

Example 3: Answering the Right Question

Question: "What does the author suggest about renewable energy adoption?"

Passage: "The slow adoption of renewable energy reflects both technological challenges and resistance from established energy industries. Despite clear environmental benefits, the transition requires significant infrastructure investment."

❌ "Renewable energy provides environmental benefits" (this answers what the passage states, not what it suggests)

✓ "Multiple barriers are slowing the transition to renewable energy" (this is the implied meaning—what the passage suggests)

5. Manage Your Time Strategically

You have 35 minutes for 4 passages (40 questions). Allocate time wisely.

Target: 8-9 minutes per passage. 3-4 minutes reading, 5-6 minutes answering. Skip difficult questions—return later if time permits. Never spend 2+ minutes on one question.

6. Use Line References to Save Time

When a question references specific lines, ALWAYS use them.

Go directly to those lines. Read 1-2 sentences before and after for context. Don't search the whole passage when given line numbers.

7. Trust the Passage Over Your Gut

Your intuition can mislead you. The passage is always right.

If an answer "sounds good" but you can't find support, it's wrong. If an answer seems weird but passage supports it, it's correct. Verify every answer against passage text.

Example 4: Passage vs. Intuition

Passage: "While solar energy reduces carbon emissions, its manufacturing process creates significant toxic waste and requires rare earth minerals extracted through environmentally damaging mining."

Question: "The passage suggests that solar energy is..."

❌ "An environmentally friendly solution to climate change" (your intuition about solar—not what passage says)

✓ "Beneficial for reducing emissions but problematic in manufacturing and sourcing" (what the passage actually says)

.

Key Takeaways

✓Every answer must have direct passage support—no outside knowledge

✓Eliminate wrong answers first before choosing the right one

✓Read actively by asking why the author included each part

✓Always answer what's asked, not what you expect the question to be

✓Spend 8-9 minutes per passage—don't rush or linger

✓Use line references when provided to save time

✓Trust passage evidence over your intuition

subject: science
title: Topic 1.1 - How to Approach the Passages
content:
Developing an efficient passage navigation strategy is crucial for success on the ACT Science section, where you must balance reading comprehension, data analysis, time management, and question-answering efficiency. Unlike the Reading section where you must engage deeply with narrative or expository text, Science passages require a different approach that prioritizes visual data interpretation over linear reading.

This lesson provides a comprehensive framework for approaching Science passages strategically, explains the optimal order for processing information, introduces techniques for efficient figure analysis, and teaches you how to extract maximum value from minimal reading.

1. The Optimal Passage Reading Sequence

The most efficient approach to Science passages follows a specific strategic sequence rather than simply reading from top to bottom. Understanding this sequence and practicing it consistently will help you work faster while maintaining high accuracy, allowing you to complete all passages within the 35-minute time limit.

Step 1: Read the Introduction Quickly

  • introductory paragraph: or first few sentences to understand
  • why:
    • . This gives you essential context about the scientific phenomenon
    • or hypothesis being investigated. For example
    • an introduction might explain that scientists are studying how temperature affects the rate of a chemical reaction
    • or that researchers are investigating factors that influence bird migration patterns
  • This context helps you understand what the variables in subsequent figures represent and why certain measurements were taken. However, don't spend more than 15-20 seconds on this initial reading—you just need the general topic and purpose, not detailed understanding. If the introduction contains complex terminology or detailed background, don't worry about understanding every word. Focus on grasping the big picture: What phenomenon or question is being studied?

Step 2: Examine All Figures and Tables First

  • figures and tables: —this is where most of the important information lives. For each figure, identify: (1)
  • what variables: are being shown (read axis labels and column headers carefully), (2)
  • what units:
    • are used (meters
    • degrees Celsius
  • what general trends:
    • are visible (do values increase
    • stay constant
    • or show a pattern?)
    • and (4) what
  • different lines, symbols, or categories:
    • represent (check the legend or key). Don't try to memorize specific data points
    • you can return to find those when answering questions
  • Instead, develop a general understanding of what each figure shows and what relationships exist between variables. This figure-first approach is efficient because 60-70% of Science questions require you to reference figures directly, and understanding the data helps you answer questions even without reading all the text.

Step 3: Skim Experimental Procedures and Descriptions

  • skim:
    • any paragraphs that describe experimental procedures
    • or methods. Your goal is to understand
  • what variables were manipulated:
    • but you don't need to memorize step-by-step procedures. For example
    • if an experiment has three trials
    • note what changed between Trial 1
    • and Trial 3 (was it temperature? concentration? time?). This understanding helps you interpret results and answer questions about experimental design
  • However, avoid reading detailed procedural descriptions word-for-word unless a question specifically asks about them. Paragraphs explaining how equipment was set up, how measurements were taken, or what specific materials were used often contain more detail than necessary for most questions. You can always return to read these sections carefully if a question requires that information.

Step 4: Move to Questions and Reference Back as Needed

  • even if you think you remember the data, check the passage to confirm. This approach prevents careless errors and is actually faster than trying to memorize all details upfront
  • Many questions will direct you to specific figures (e.g., "According to Figure 2..."), making it easy to know where to look. For questions without explicit references, use the question number as a guide
  • early questions typically relate to early parts of the passage, while later questions often address later sections
  • This question-focused approach ensures you're spending time on information that actually matters for points rather than reading details that won't be tested
  • Passage Preview:
    • : A Research Summaries passage with 3 experiments testing how pH
    • temperature
    • and concentration affect enzyme activity
  • Step 1 (20 seconds):: Read intro → "Scientists studied factors affecting enzyme activity"
  • Step 2 (45 seconds):
    • : Examine all three figures → Note that Figure 1 shows pH vs. activity
    • Figure 2 shows temperature vs. activity
    • Figure 3 shows concentration vs. activity
  • Step 3 (30 seconds):
    • : Skim experiment descriptions → Trial 1 varied pH
    • Trial 2 varied temperature
    • Trial 3 varied concentration
  • Step 4 (3-4 minutes):: Answer all 6 questions, referencing specific figures and text as needed Total time: approximately 5 minutes per passage

2. Figure-First vs. Text-First Reading Approaches

One of the most important strategic decisions you'll make is whether to adopt a figure-first approach or a text-first approach. While most high-scoring students favor the figure-first method, understanding both approaches and their variations helps you identify what works best for your learning style and adapt to different passage types.

The Figure-First Approach (Recommended for Most Students)

  • The figure-first approach prioritizes examining graphs, tables, and diagrams before reading detailed text
  • This method works well because Science questions primarily test data interpretation skills, and most answers can be found by analyzing figures.
  • After a brief intro reading, you spend the majority of your initial passage time studying figures to understand what variables are present, what trends exist, and how different trials or conditions compare.
  • Then you skim text only as needed to clarify what the figures show or to understand experimental differences
  • This approach is particularly effective for Data Representation passages where figures dominate and text is minimal, but it also works well for many Research Summaries passages.
  • The main advantage is time efficiency—you focus on the information that matters most. The potential disadvantage is that you might miss important context or definitions that would make figure interpretation easier, though this is rare since figures are usually self-explanatory with proper labels..

The Text-First Approach (Better for Some Conflicting Viewpoints Passages)

  • text-first approach: involves reading the passage more thoroughly before examining figures in depth. This method can be effective for
  • Conflicting Viewpoints passages: which contain substantial text describing different scientific perspectives and may have fewer or simpler figures. When different scientists or students present competing theories, understanding the logic and evidence behind each viewpoint often requires careful reading of the arguments presented
  • In these cases, reading the text first provides context that makes subsequent figure analysis more meaningful. However, even with this approach, you should still
  • skim rather than read every word: focusing on understanding the main claims and differences between viewpoints
  • The main disadvantage of text-first for Data Representation and Research Summaries passages is that it often wastes time on details that won't be tested, causing you to run short on time for later passages.

The Hybrid Approach (Questions-First Method)

Some students prefer a hybrid approach where they quickly preview the questions first to know what information they'll need, then strategically read only the relevant parts of the passage. For example, if you see that questions 1-3 all reference Figure 1, you might examine Figure 1 carefully while only glancing at Figures 2 and 3.

Or if a question asks specifically about what was held constant in Trial 2, you know to focus on that experimental description. This approach can be highly efficient because it ensures you're never reading irrelevant information.

However, it requires strong mental organization to track what you've looked for and what you still need to find. It can also be disruptive if you're constantly jumping between questions and passage sections.

This method works best for students who are comfortable with non-linear reading and have already developed strong figure-reading skills through practice.

Adapting Your Approach by Passage Type

  • adapt your approach: based on passage type and complexity. For straightforward
  • Data Representation passages: with simple graphs and minimal text, a strict figure-first approach usually works best. For
  • Research Summaries passages:
    • with multiple experiments
    • you might spend more time reading experimental descriptions to understand how trials differ
    • though you should still prioritize figures. For
  • Conflicting Viewpoints passages: you may need to read the text more carefully to understand each scientist's reasoning, though you should still examine any accompanying figures
  • Some students also adjust their strategy based on passage difficulty—spending more time on initial reading for complex passages and less for straightforward ones. Flexibility is valuable, but make sure you're making conscious strategic decisions rather than just reading randomly or inconsistently.

Example: Choosing Your Approach

Data Representation Passage: 3 figures showing temperature vs. pressure relationships → Use figure-first approach, spend 60+ seconds examining graphs, minimal text reading

Research Summaries Passage: 3 experiments with detailed procedures and result tables → Use figure-first but allocate more time to skimming experimental descriptions

Conflicting Viewpoints Passage: Scientists A and B debate climate change mechanisms → Read text more thoroughly to understand each perspective, but still check figures for supporting evidence

Experiment with different approaches during practice to find what maximizes your accuracy and speed.

3. Efficient Figure and Table Analysis Techniques

Since figures and tables contain the majority of information needed to answer Science questions, developing systematic figure analysis skills is essential. Learning to extract key information quickly and accurately from visual data representations will dramatically improve both your speed and accuracy on the Science section.

The Five-Element Figure Analysis Framework

  • Variables - What is being measured or manipulated? Read all axis labels and table headers.
  • Units - What units are used for each variable? (meters, grams, seconds, etc.) Pay attention to unit prefixes like "k" for kilo or "m" for milli.
  • Scale - What range of values is shown? Does the axis start at zero or some other value? Is the scale linear or logarithmic?
  • Trends - How do the variables relate to each other? Do values increase together (positive correlation), move in opposite directions (inverse relationship), or show no clear pattern?
  • Legend/Key - What do different lines, symbols, colors, or categories represent? Making this five-element check habitual ensures you never miss important details that could cause errors.

Common Figure Types and How to Read Them

  • ACT Science passages use several standard figure types, each requiring slightly different reading strategies. Line graphs show how one variable changes with another
  • focus on the overall trend (increasing, decreasing, constant) and whether the relationship is linear or curved. Bar graphs compare values across categories
  • look for which category has the highest or lowest value and how much they differ. Scatter plots show relationships between two variables with individual data points
  • look for general patterns or clusters. Data tables organize values in rows and columns
  • identify what each row and column represents and notice patterns as you move across rows or down columns. Diagrams illustrate experimental setups or scientific processes
  • understand what each labeled component represents and how they interact. Recognizing these common types helps you quickly orient yourself and know what to look for

Identifying Trends and Relationships

Many Science questions ask about trends and relationships between variables. When examining figures, actively ask yourself: How do the variables relate? Common relationship types include:

  • positive/direct relationship (both variables increase together), negative/inverse relationship (one increases while the other decreases), no relationship (changes in one variable don't affect the other)
  • linear relationship (the relationship forms a straight line), non-linear relationship (the relationship is curved), and exponential relationship (the rate of change accelerates)
  • Being able to quickly identify these relationship types allows you to answer trend questions without needing to read specific values
  • You should also notice whether trends are consistent across the entire range shown or whether the relationship changes at certain points

Avoiding Common Figure-Reading Mistakes

  • Confusing x and y variables:
    • is extremely common
    • always check which variable is on which axis
  • Misreading scales:
    • causes many errors
    • especially when axes don't start at zero or use non-standard intervals (like going 0
    • 500 instead of evenly spaced values)
  • Ignoring units: can lead to errors when comparing values from different figures or when units change within a passage.
  • Misidentifying which line or symbol:
    • represents which condition is another frequent mistake
    • always double-check the legend
  • Extrapolating too far beyond the data:
    • shown can also cause errors
    • be cautious when predicting values outside the measured range
  • Slowing down for just 2-3 extra seconds to verify these details prevents careless mistakes that cost points.

Example: Systematic Figure Analysis

Figure 1: Graph showing "Temperature (°C)" on x-axis and "Reaction Rate (mol/sec)" on y-axis

Variables: Temperature and Reaction Rate
Units: Temperature in °C, Reaction Rate in mol/sec
Scale: x-axis goes from 0-80°C in intervals of 20; y-axis goes from 0-5 mol/sec in intervals of 1
Trend: As temperature increases, reaction rate increases (positive relationship, appears to be exponential)
Legend: One line shown, labeled "Enzyme A"

This 15-second analysis prepares you to answer most questions about this figure without needing to re-examine it repeatedly.

4. Maximizing Efficiency Through Strategic Passage Selection

  • choosing which passages to tackle first based on your strengths and passage characteristics
  • can significantly improve your score by ensuring you maximize points earned within the time limit and maintain confidence and momentum throughout the section

Identifying Your Strongest Passage Types

  • Data Representation passages: quickest because they have minimal text and straightforward graph-reading questions. Others prefer
  • Research Summaries passages: because they enjoy the logical structure of experimental design. Some students find
  • Conflicting Viewpoints passages: most accessible because they involve reading comprehension skills similar to the Reading section. Understanding your preferences allows you to develop a
  • personalized passage order strategy:
    • . For example
    • if you're strongest at Data Representation
    • you might quickly flip through the section at the start
    • identify the 2-3 Data Representation passages by their figure-heavy layouts
  • complete those first. This approach ensures you secure easy points quickly and build confidence before tackling more challenging passages.

Quick Passage Previewing Technique

  • How many figures does each passage have? Passages with more complex or dense figures may take longer.
  • How much text is present? Text-heavy passages (usually Conflicting Viewpoints) may require more reading time.
  • Do any passages cover topics you're familiar with? While outside knowledge isn't required, comfort with a topic can boost confidence.
  • Are there any passages with particularly simple-looking graphs or tables? These might be quick wins

Based on this preview, mentally rank the passages from most to least approachable and tackle them in that order. However, be careful not to spend too much time previewing—if this takes more than 45 seconds, it's probably not worth it.

Some students prefer to just start with the first passage rather than risk wasting time on decision-making.

Banking Time with Faster Passages

The strategy of completing easier passages first has another advantage: banking time for more difficult passages. If you can complete a straightforward Data Representation passage in 3.5 minutes instead of 5 minutes, you've saved 1.5 minutes that you can apply to a more complex Research Summaries or Conflicting Viewpoints passage later.

This flexibility is crucial because some passages genuinely do take longer than others due to complexity, and rigid pacing (exactly 5 minutes per passage) doesn't account for this variability. By working efficiently on easier passages, you create a time buffer that reduces stress and allows you to think more carefully about challenging questions.

However, don't rush through easier passages so quickly that you make careless errors—the time you save isn't worth it if you miss questions you should have gotten right. Aim for efficient accuracy, not just speed.

Managing Difficult Passages Strategically

  • not all questions within a passage are equally difficult: . Even in a challenging passage, there are usually 2-3 straightforward questions that ask for simple data reading or basic trends
  • Tackle those first to secure easy points. For genuinely difficult questions that would require extensive time, consider
  • strategic guessing: —if you've spent 60 seconds on a question and still aren't sure, make your best guess and move on rather than spending 2-3 minutes agonizing over one question. You can also employ the strategy of
  • saving one passage for last: —if you reach the final passage with only 3 minutes remaining
  • answer the easiest questions you can identify and guess on the rest rather than running out of time completely.
  • Your Science section contains:: Passage 1: Research Summaries (3 experiments, dense text) - MEDIUM DIFFICULTY - Passage 2: Data Representation (simple line graphs)
  • EASY - Passage 3: Conflicting Viewpoints (lots of text) - HARD - Passage 4: Data Representation (multiple tables) - EASY - Passage 5: Research Summaries (2 experiments) - MEDIUM - Passage 6: Data Representation (scatter plots) - MEDIUM
  • Optimal order:: 2 → 4 → 6 → 1 → 5 → 3 (easy passages first, hardest last) This ensures you secure maximum points on straightforward passages before tackling the time-consuming Conflicting Viewpoints passage.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Follow the optimal sequence: brief intro reading → examine all figures → skim procedures → answer questions
  • ✓Prioritize figures and tables over text—60-70% of questions can be answered primarily from visual data
  • ✓Use the figure-first approach for Data Representation and most Research Summaries passages
  • ✓Read text more carefully for Conflicting Viewpoints passages to understand different scientific perspectives
  • ✓Systematically analyze every figure: variables, units, scale, trends, and legend/key
  • ✓Identify relationships between variables: positive, negative, linear, non-linear, or exponential
  • ✓Avoid common mistakes: confusing x/y variables, misreading scales, ignoring units, and wrong legend interpretation
  • ✓Complete passages in strategic order—identify and tackle your strongest passage types first
  • ✓Bank time by working efficiently on easier passages, giving yourself extra time for complex ones
  • ✓Don't spend more than 60 seconds struggling with one question—guess and move on if necessary
