title: Topic 2.6 - Scatter Plots
content:
• identify correlations: between two variables
  • assess correlation strength:
    • from point dispersion. Unlike line graphs that connect sequential data points to show change over time
    • scatter plots display individual data points to reveal whether two variables are related and how strongly. This lesson teaches you systematic techniques for reading scatter plots
    • explains how to identify positive
  • no-correlation patterns, provides strategies for distinguishing correlation from causation, and shows you how to make predictions using best-fit lines or trends visible in scattered data.

1. Understanding Scatter Plot Structure and Purpose

Scatter plots show individual data points plotted with one variable on the x-axis and another on the y-axis, revealing whether and how the variables are correlated (related to each other).

What Scatter Plots Show Versus Line Graphs

  • Line graphs connect points to show how a single variable changes over time or with respect to another variable in a controlled experiment. They emphasize trends and progression.
  • Scatter plots display individual observations or measurements to show whether two variables are related across many samples

They emphasize correlation patterns. (3) Line graphs assume order matters (usually temporal or sequential), so points are connected. (4) Scatter plots don't assume order—each point represents a separate observation, sample, or subject. For example, a scatter plot might show height versus weight for 50 different people (50 separate data points), while a line graph might show how one person's weight changed over 50 weeks (50 connected sequential measurements)

On the ACT, scatter plots typically appear when studies measure two characteristics across many subjects or samples to see if they're related.

Reading Individual Data Points on Scatter Plots

To read individual points on a scatter plot: (1) Locate the point of interest on the graph. (2) Trace straight down to the x-axis to read the x-coordinate (the first variable's value). (3) Trace straight left to the y-axis to read the y-coordinate (the second variable's value). (4) This point represents one observation where both variables were measured. For example, if you see a point at x=15, y=30, this might represent one student who studied 15 hours (x) and scored 30 points (y) on a test

Questions might ask: "How many students studied more than 20 hours?" (count points where x > 20), or "What was the highest score achieved?" (find the point with the highest y-value). These are straightforward reading tasks similar to other graph types, but you're reading individual points rather than connected lines.

Understanding Best-Fit Lines and Trend Lines

  • The best-fit line shows the general trend of the relationship between variables. It's positioned to minimize the distance to all points collectively.
  • Individual points rarely fall exactly on the line

Instead, they scatter around it. The line represents the average or expected relationship. (3) The slope of the best-fit line indicates the direction and strength of the relationship

Steep slopes indicate strong relationships; gentle slopes indicate weak relationships. (4) Best-fit lines are used for prediction. If you want to estimate the y-value for an x-value not measured, use the line rather than individual points.

For example, if the scatter plot shows data for x = 10, 15, 20, 25 but the best-fit line is drawn through all points, you can trace from x = 18 up to the line and over to the y-axis to estimate the expected y-value at x = 18. The best-fit line smooths out individual variation to show the underlying pattern.

Recognizing Scatter Plot Contexts on the ACT

  • Observational studies:
    • Researchers measure two characteristics across many subjects (height vs. arm length
    • temperature vs. species diversity
    • income vs. education level) to see if they're related
  • Comparisons across different samples or locations:
    • Different schools
    • or ecosystems measured for two variables to see if patterns exist
  • Multi-trial experiments: Each data point represents a separate experimental trial with slightly different conditions, showing how two measured outcomes relate.
  • Population or sample surveys:
    • Data collected from individuals in a population
    • plotted to show relationships between characteristics. The key identifier is that each point represents a separate entity (person
    • sample) rather than sequential measurements of the same thing over time

Understanding this context helps you interpret what the scatter plot represents.

  • Scatter plot shows:
    • : X-axis = "Hours of sunlight per day" (0-10)
    • Y-axis = "Plant height (cm)" (0-50) Contains 20 data points scattered across the plot Best-fit line slopes upward from (0
  • Reading individual point:: One point at x=6, y=30 → One plant received 6 hours of sunlight and grew to 30 cm
  • Using best-fit line:: Question asks "Based on the trend, what height would be expected at 7 hours of sunlight?" Method: Trace from x=7 up to the best-fit line → horizontally to y-axis → approximately y=32 cm
  • Interpretation:: The scatter plot shows many different plants (each point = one plant)
  • The best-fit line shows the general relationship:
    • more sunlight → taller plants. Individual plants vary (some above the line
    • some below)
    • but the trend is clear

2. Identifying Types of Correlations

The most common scatter plot questions ask you to identify the type of correlation (relationship) between the two variables: positive, negative, or no correlation.

Recognizing Positive Correlation

  • Visual pattern: Points trend upward from lower-left to upper-right. The cloud of points slopes upward.
  • Best-fit line (if shown) has a positive slope (rising as you move right).
  • Interpretation: Higher x-values are associated with higher y-values.
  • Examples:
    • Height vs. weight (taller people tend to weigh more)
    • study time vs. test score (more study tends to yield higher scores)
    • temperature vs. reaction rate (higher temperature tends to increase rate)

To confirm positive correlation: Pick a low x-value and note the typical y-values at that x. Then pick a high x-value and note typical y-values there.

If y-values are generally higher at high x-values than at low x-values, the correlation is positive. ACT questions might ask: "Which statement best describes the relationship between X and Y?" and the correct answer for positive correlation would be something like "As X increases, Y tends to increase" or "X and Y are positively correlated".

Recognizing Negative Correlation

  • Visual pattern: Points trend downward from upper-left to lower-right. The cloud of points slopes downward.
  • Best-fit line (if shown) has a negative slope (falling as you move right).
  • Interpretation: Higher x-values are associated with lower y-values.
  • Examples:
    • Altitude vs. air pressure (higher altitude → lower pressure)
    • speed vs. fuel efficiency (faster driving → lower mpg)
    • predator population vs. prey population (more predators → fewer prey)

To confirm negative correlation: Compare y-values at low x-values versus high x-values. If y-values are generally lower at high x-values than at low x-values, the correlation is negative.

ACT questions might phrase this as: "As X increases, Y tends to decrease" or "X and Y are negatively correlated" or "X and Y show an inverse relationship". Don't confuse negative correlation with bad or wrong—it's simply a description of the direction of the relationship.

Recognizing No Correlation (Random Pattern)

  • Visual pattern: Points are scattered randomly with no clear upward or downward trend. The cloud of points shows no directional pattern.
  • Best-fit line (if shown) would be approximately horizontal, or might not be shown at all since there's no meaningful trend.
  • Interpretation: Y-values don't change systematically with x-values

High and low y-values occur at all x-values. (4) Examples: Shoe size vs. test score (unrelated), hair color vs. height (unrelated for adults), student ID number vs. GPA (unrelated)

To confirm no correlation: Check if y-values are similar across all x-values. If the range and average of y-values is roughly the same at low, medium, and high x-values, there's no correlation.

ACT answer choices might say: "There is no relationship between X and Y" or "X and Y are not correlated" or "Changes in X do not affect Y". No correlation indicates the variables are independent.

Assessing Correlation Strength: Strong Versus Weak

Beyond direction (positive/negative), correlations vary in strength: (1) Strong correlation: Points cluster tightly around the best-fit line or trend. There's little scatter or deviation.

Knowing X gives you a good prediction of Y. (2) Weak correlation: Points are loosely scattered around the trend. There's substantial deviation from the line

X provides only a rough prediction of Y. (3) Visual assessment: The tighter the clustering around the trend line, the stronger the correlation. The more scattered or dispersed the points, the weaker the correlation. (4) ACT questions might ask: "Which graph shows the strongest positive correlation?" (choose the one where points cluster most tightly around an upward trend) or "Is the relationship between X and Y strong or weak?" (assess point dispersion)

You can have strong positive correlation (tight upward pattern), weak positive correlation (loose upward pattern), strong negative correlation (tight downward pattern), or weak negative correlation (loose downward pattern). Strength and direction are independent characteristics.

  • Positive Correlation:: Pattern: Points slope upward from lower-left to upper-right Description: "As hours of exercise per week increases
  • cardiovascular fitness score tends to increase" Answer choice: "Exercise and fitness are positively correlated"
  • Negative Correlation:: Pattern: Points slope downward from upper-left to lower-right Description: "As number of absences increases, final grade tends to decrease" Answer choice: "Absences and grades are negatively correlated"
  • No Correlation:: Pattern: Points scattered randomly with no clear trend Description: "Birth month shows no relationship with test score" Answer choice: "There is no correlation between birth month and test performance"
  • Strong vs. Weak:: Strong positive: Points cluster tightly along upward line Weak positive: Points show upward tendency but are widely scattered Assessment: "The correlation is positive but weak due to high variability"

3. Correlation Versus Causation

A critical concept for scatter plot questions is understanding that correlation does not equal causation. Just because two variables are related doesn't mean one causes the other.

Understanding the Correlation-Causation Distinction

Correlation means two variables are statistically related—they change together in a predictable pattern. Causation means one variable directly causes changes in the other.

The key distinctions: (1) Correlation can be observed from data. If a scatter plot shows that X and Y increase together, they're correlated. (2) Causation requires experimental evidence or theoretical mechanism.

You can't determine causation from correlation alone. (3) Three possibilities when variables correlate: (a) X causes Y, (b) Y causes X, (c) Some third variable causes both X and Y, making them correlated even though neither causes the other. (4) Example: Ice cream sales and drowning deaths are positively correlated. Does ice cream cause drowning? No

Does drowning cause ice cream sales? No. A third variable (summer/hot weather) causes both: hot weather increases ice cream sales AND increases swimming (which increases drowning risk).

The variables correlate but neither causes the other. The ACT often tests whether you understand this distinction.

Recognizing Causal Language Versus Correlation Language

ACT answer choices are carefully worded to distinguish correlation from causation: Correlation language (appropriate for scatter plots): "X and Y are related", "X is associated with Y", "As X increases, Y tends to increase", "X and Y are positively correlated". These describe the pattern without claiming causation.

Causal language (usually inappropriate for simple scatter plots): "X causes Y", "Increasing X will increase Y", "Y is a result of X", "X produces Y". These claim that one variable directly causes the other.

  • Look for correlation language in answer choices if the scatter plot simply shows observational data.
  • Eliminate answers using causal language unless the passage explicitly describes an experimental manipulation where one variable was controlled to test its effect on the other.
  • The safest interpretation of scatter plots is correlation, not causation, unless additional context supports causation.

When Causation Can Be Inferred

  • The passage describes a controlled experiment where researchers manipulated one variable (independent variable) and measured its effect on another (dependent variable). If the scatter plot shows results from such an experiment, causation may be appropriate.
  • There's a clear temporal order: the x-variable occurs before the y-variable, making reverse causation impossible.
  • A theoretical mechanism is described explaining how X affects Y.
  • Other variables were controlled, ruling out third-variable explanations

For example, if the passage says "Students were randomly assigned to different study time amounts (5, 10, 15, or 20 hours) and then tested", a scatter plot showing study time vs. score can support causation because study time was experimentally manipulated. But if the passage says "Researchers surveyed students about how much they studied and their scores", the same scatter plot would only show correlation—students who study more might also be more motivated, better prepared, or differ in other ways.

Read the passage context carefully to determine whether causal language is justified.

Common Third-Variable Explanations

Many correlations result from third variables (confounding variables) that influence both measured variables: (1) Example 1: Foot size and reading ability are positively correlated in children. Does big feet cause better reading? No.

Age is the third variable—older children have bigger feet AND better reading skills due to more schooling. (2) Example 2: Umbrella sales and raincoat sales are positively correlated. Do umbrellas cause raincoat purchases? No.

Rainy weather causes both. (3) Example 3: Cities with more hospitals have higher death rates. Do hospitals cause deaths? No

Population size is the third variable—larger cities have both more hospitals AND more deaths simply because more people live there. (4) On the ACT: Questions might present a correlation and ask what could explain it. Look for answer choices that mention plausible third variables rather than assuming direct causation

Understanding third-variable explanations helps you avoid incorrectly inferring causation from correlation patterns.

  • Scenario:: Scatter plot shows positive correlation between number of firefighters at a fire scene and amount of fire damage
  • Wrong interpretation (causation):: "More firefighters cause more damage"
  • Correct interpretation (correlation):: "Number of firefighters and damage are positively correlated"
  • Explanation:
    • : Fire severity is the third variable
    • bigger fires require more firefighters AND cause more damage
  • ACT Question:: "Based on the scatter plot, which statement is supported?"
  • Eliminate:: "Increasing the number of firefighters increases fire damage" (causal claim not supported)
  • Select:: "Fires with more firefighters present tend to have greater damage" (correlation, correctly stated) The scatter plot shows the pattern but doesn't prove that firefighters cause damage
  • Understanding this distinction is critical for selecting correctly worded answers.

4. Using Scatter Plots for Prediction and Analysis

Beyond identifying correlation types, scatter plot questions often ask you to make predictions, identify outliers, or analyze specific features of the data distribution.

Using Best-Fit Lines for Interpolation and Extrapolation

  • Interpolation (within the data range):
    • If data points exist for x = 10
    • 40 and you need to predict y at x = 25
    • trace from x = 25 up to the best-fit line
    • then left to the y-axis. The line represents the expected average value
  • Extrapolation (beyond the data range): If data exists for x = 10 to 40 and you need to predict at x = 50, extend the best-fit line mentally or with your pencil and trace from x = 50

This is less reliable than interpolation but gives a reasonable estimate if the trend continues. (3) Use the line, not individual points. Individual points show variation; the line shows the underlying relationship. (4) Questions might ask: "Based on the trend, what would be the expected y-value at x = 35?" Use the best-fit line, not the scattered points

This approach smooths out individual variation to make the most accurate prediction based on the overall pattern.

Identifying and Interpreting Outliers

  • Visual identification: Outliers are points that are far from the best-fit line or from the main cluster of points.
  • Interpretation:
    • Outliers might represent unusual cases
    • measurement errors
    • special conditions
    • or exceptions to the general rule
  • ACT questions might ask:
    • "Which data point is an outlier?" (choose the one farthest from the trend)
    • "What might explain the outlier point at (x
    • y)?" (look for answer choices suggesting unusual conditions or errors)
    • or "If the outlier were removed
    • how would the correlation change?" (often it would strengthen the correlation because the outlying point was weakening it)
  • Don't ignore outliers in interpretation—they're often meaningful. They might represent important exceptions or indicate that the relationship isn't as simple as the trend suggests

However, for making predictions about typical cases, the best-fit line (which isn't heavily influenced by one or two outliers) is more useful than outlier points.

Comparing Multiple Scatter Plots

  • Comparing correlation strength: Which shows the strongest correlation? Choose the one where points cluster most tightly around a trend.
  • Comparing correlation direction: Which shows positive versus negative correlation? Look at slope direction.
  • Comparing slopes: Which shows the steepest relationship? Choose the plot with the steepest best-fit line.
  • Comparing ranges or distributions:
    • Which has the most variability in Y? Look at the spread of y-values. To systematically compare: Create a simple mental checklist: For each plot
    • note (a) correlation direction (positive/negative/none)
    • (b) correlation strength (strong/weak)
    • (c) approximate slope
    • (d) presence of outliers

Then compare these characteristics to answer the question. For example, if asked "Which plot shows the weakest relationship?", choose the one with the most scattered points or the flattest slope.

Understanding Non-Linear Patterns in Scatter Plots

  • Curved patterns:
    • Points might follow a curve rather than a straight line. For example
    • they might increase rapidly at first then level off (logarithmic)
    • or increase slowly at first then rapidly (exponential)
  • U-shaped or inverted-U patterns: Variables might be related but not in a simple one-direction way

For example, temperature vs.

  • Recognition: If points don't scatter around a straight line but instead follow a curved path, the relationship is non-linear.
  • ACT questions might ask:
    • "Which best describes the relationship?" For non-linear patterns, choose answers like "Y increases at a decreasing rate as X increases" (logarithmic) or "Y initially increases then decreases as X increases" (inverted-U). Don't try to fit every pattern into simple positive/negative linear correlation
    • recognize when patterns are more complex
  • Scatter plot shows:
    • : X-axis = "Temperature (°C)" from 0-100
    • Y-axis = "Reaction rate (units/sec)" from 0-50 Data points show positive correlation with best-fit line from (0
    • 45) One outlier point at (50
    • 15) is well below the line
  • Question 1:
    • : "Based on the trend
    • what reaction rate would be expected at 60°C?" Method: Trace from x=60 up to best-fit line (not to individual points)
    • then to y-axis → approximately 29 units/sec Answer: 29 units/sec
  • Question 2:
    • : "Which data point is an outlier?" Analysis: Point at (50
    • 15) is far below the trend line while all others cluster near it Answer: The point at 50°C
    • 15 units/sec
  • Question 3:: "How would removing the outlier affect the correlation?" Analysis: Removing a point that's far from the trend would make remaining points cluster more tightly Answer: The correlation would become stronger

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Scatter plots show individual data points to reveal correlations between two variables across many observations
  • ✓Positive correlation: points trend upward (both variables increase together); negative correlation: points trend downward
  • ✓No correlation: points scattered randomly with no clear directional pattern
  • ✓Correlation strength is shown by point clustering: tight clustering = strong, loose scattering = weak
  • ✓Best-fit lines show the general trend and are used for prediction, not individual points which show variation
  • ✓Correlation does not equal causation—correlated variables might not have a cause-effect relationship
  • ✓Choose correlation language ("associated with", "related to") not causal language ("causes") for observational data
  • ✓Third variables can cause two variables to correlate even when neither causes the other
  • ✓Outliers are points far from the trend; they may represent unusual cases, errors, or important exceptions
  • ✓For prediction questions, use the best-fit line to interpolate (within data range) or extrapolate (beyond data range)
