title: Topic 2.7 - Inverse Trends and Graphs with Multiple Axes
content:
• recognize opposing relationships: where one variable increases while another decreases
  • interpret graphs with two y-axes: showing different variables on left and right sides
  • understand how to read multiple trend lines:
    • simultaneously. Unlike simple upward or downward trend questions that focus on a single variable's behavior
    • these questions require you to track multiple variables that may move in different directions
    • carefully determine which axis corresponds to which variable
  • understand the relationship between variables that have inverse or complementary patterns. This lesson teaches you systematic approaches for handling graphs with opposing trends, explains how to correctly read dual-axis graphs without confusing which variable uses which scale, provides strategies for identifying inverse relationships quickly and accurately, and shows you how to answer questions that require comparing or contrasting variables with different directional behaviors.

1. Understanding Inverse Trends and Negative Correlations

Inverse trends (also called negative correlations or inverse relationships) occur when two variables move in opposite directions: as one increases, the other decreases.

Recognizing Inverse Relationships in Single Graphs

  • Visual pattern: The line or curve slopes downward from left to right. As x increases, y decreases.
  • Common examples:
    • Altitude vs. air pressure (higher altitude → lower pressure)
    • speed vs. fuel efficiency (faster speed → lower mpg)
    • predator population vs. prey population (more predators → fewer prey)
  • Terminology:
    • These might be described as "inverse relationship"
    • "negative correlation"
    • "indirect relationship"
    • or simply "as X increases
    • Y decreases"
  • ACT questions might ask: "How does increasing temperature affect the amount of dissolved gas?" If the graph shows a downward trend, the answer is "it decreases" or "they are inversely related"

The key recognition pattern is a downward-sloping line or curve, indicating that the two variables move in opposite directions. This is straightforward when only one variable is plotted against the x-axis.

Identifying Inverse Trends When Multiple Variables Are Shown

  • Look for opposing slopes. If one line goes up while another goes down (as you move left to right), they have an inverse relationship with respect to the x-variable.
  • Example: A graph might show "reactant concentration" decreasing over time while "product concentration" increases over time
  • Check the question carefully. Is it asking about the relationship between a variable and the x-axis (time, temperature, etc.), or between two y-variables (both plotted against the same x-axis)?
  • ACT questions might ask:
    • "What is the relationship between reactant concentration and product concentration?" If one decreases while the other increases
    • answer "inverse" or "as reactant decreases
    • product increases"

The key is comparing directional trends of different variables, not just observing a single downward slope.

Understanding the Practical Meaning of Inverse Trends

  • Conservation or transformation:
    • One thing is converted into another (reactants → products
    • potential energy → kinetic energy). As one decreases
    • the other increases because mass or energy is conserved
  • Competition or trade-offs:
    • Resources are limited
    • so more of X means less of Y (more predators → fewer prey
    • more time spent on A → less time for B)
  • Physical limitations: Physical laws create inverse relationships (higher temperature → lower density for gases, higher pressure → lower volume for gases).
  • Opposite effects: A factor that increases one variable decreases another (adding acid increases H⁺ concentration but decreases pH)

Understanding why inverse trends occur helps you interpret them correctly and predict behavior. If you understand that reactants are consumed to create products, you can predict that reactant decrease and product increase will be inversely related even without seeing the graph.

This conceptual understanding supports your graph interpretation skills.

Distinguishing Inverse Trends from Independent Variables

Not all variables that behave differently are inversely related—some are simply independent (unrelated): (1) Inverse relationship: Consistently, when one goes up, the other goes down. There's a predictable opposing pattern. (2) Independent (unrelated) variables: No consistent pattern.

  • Example of inverse: Temperature and viscosity of honey (higher temperature → consistently lower viscosity).
  • Example of independent:
    • Student height and test score (no consistent relationship
    • tall and short students can have any score)

To identify inverse trends: Look for consistent opposing patterns throughout the data range. If the opposition is consistent, it's an inverse relationship.

If the pattern is inconsistent or random, the variables are independent. ACT questions specifically asking about inverse relationships will show data where the inverse pattern is clear and consistent.

  • Graph shows:
    • : X-axis = Time (0-60 min)
    • Two lines plotted: - Line A (Reactant): Starts at 100%
    • decreases to 20% - Line B (Product): Starts at 0%
    • increases to 80%
  • Question 1:: "What is the relationship between reactant concentration and time?" Analysis: As time increases (left to right), reactant decreases Answer: "Inverse relationship" or "Reactant decreases as time increases"
  • Question 2:: "What is the relationship between reactant concentration and product concentration?" Analysis: As reactant decreases
  • product increases (lines move in opposite directions) Answer: "Inverse relationship" or "As reactant decreases, product increases"
  • Interpretation:
    • : The inverse trend makes sense
    • reactant is being consumed to form product, so as one decreases the other increases. This is a transformation/conservation type of inverse relationship

2. Reading and Interpreting Dual-Axis Graphs

Dual-axis graphs (also called double y-axis graphs) have two different y-axis scales—one on the left and one on the right—allowing two variables with different units or value ranges to be plotted on the same graph.

Understanding Why Dual Axes Are Used

Dual axes solve a visualization problem: (1) Problem: Sometimes you want to show two variables on the same graph to compare their trends over time or with respect to another variable, but they have very different scales. For example, temperature (20-30°C) and pressure (0.5-2.5 atm)

If you used a single y-axis for both, one variable would be squished and hard to read. (2) Solution: Use two y-axes—left axis for one variable, right axis for the other. Each variable gets its own appropriate scale. (3) Benefit: You can see both variables' trends clearly and compare their patterns (do they both increase? Do they move inversely?) even though their actual numerical values are on different scales. (4) Common use: Comparing related variables with different units (temperature and volume, population and food supply, concentration and pH)

Recognizing that dual axes serve this practical purpose helps you understand why a graph is structured this way and what comparisons it's meant to facilitate.

The Critical Skill: Matching Variables to the Correct Axis

  • Look for visual cues:
    • the line color or style (solid vs. dashed) matches the axis label. If the left axis is labeled in blue and one line is blue
    • that line uses the left axis
  • Check the legend: The legend should specify which variable uses which axis

It might say "Temperature (left axis)" and "Pressure (right axis)". (3) Check units: If the left axis shows 0-100 and is labeled "°C" and one line's values range from 20-80, that line probably uses the left axis. If the right axis shows 0-5 and is labeled "atm" and another line ranges from 1-4, it uses the right axis. (4) Read axis labels carefully: Make sure you're reading the correct axis for the variable in question

This seems obvious, but it's the most common error on dual-axis questions. Students read values from the wrong axis and get incorrect answers.

Always verify which axis corresponds to the variable you're being asked about before reading any values.

Step-by-Step Process for Reading Dual-Axis Graphs

Use this systematic approach: (1) Read the question and identify which variable(s) it asks about.

  • Determine which axis that variable uses. Check the legend, axis labels, or visual cues to confirm temperature uses the left axis (for example).
  • Locate the x-value in the question

Find t=20 min on the x-axis. (4) Trace up from that x-value to the correct line (the one for temperature). (5) From that point on the line, trace horizontally to the CORRECT y-axis (the left axis for temperature). (6) Read the value from that axis. This methodical approach prevents the common error of reading from the wrong axis

For example, if you need temperature (left axis) but accidentally read from the right axis, you'll get the pressure value instead, leading to a wrong answer. Taking an extra 5 seconds to verify the correct axis saves you from this error.

Comparing Trends Across Both Axes

  • "Do both variables increase?" Look at both lines—do they both slope upward?
  • "Do they show an inverse relationship?" Does one slope upward while the other slopes downward?
  • "At what time were both variables at their maximum?" Find where each line peaks and check if these occur at the same x-value.
  • "Which variable changed more dramatically?" Look at the proportional change for each (compare starting to ending values relative to each variable's scale). For these questions, you're comparing the shapes and directions of the two lines, not their absolute values
  • you're just looking at whether each line goes up, down, or stays flat, and whether these directions match or oppose each other. This is actually easier than value-reading questions because you don't need to worry about which axis is which
  • you're just comparing line directions visually
  • Graph structure:
    • : X-axis: Time (0-60 min) - Left y-axis: Temperature (°C)
    • range 0-100
  • Right y-axis:
    • Pressure (atm)
    • red label - Blue solid line (temperature): increases from 20°C to 80°C - Red dashed line (pressure): increases from 1 atm to 4 atm
  • Question 1:: "What was the temperature at t=30 min?" Step 1: Identify variable → temperature Step 2: Determine axis → temperature uses left (blue) axis Step 3: Find t=30 on x-axis Step 4: Trace up to blue line Step 5: Trace left to left y-axis Step 6: Read value → approximately 50°C CRITICAL: Don't read from right axis (that would give pressure, not temperature)
  • Question 2:: "What is the relationship between temperature and pressure over time?" Analysis: Both lines slope upward → both increase as time increases Answer: "Both temperature and pressure increase over time" or "They show a positive relationship" The key is always verifying which axis matches which variable before reading values.

3. Advanced Inverse Trend Patterns

Complex inverse patterns go beyond simple "one up, one down" and require more sophisticated analysis of how multiple variables interact.

Mirror-Image Inverse Trends

  • Pattern:
    • When one variable is at its maximum
    • the other is at its minimum. When one increases by X units
    • the other decreases by X units
  • Example: In a closed container, % nitrogen and % oxygen might be inversely related
  • Graphically: The lines appear to be mirror images across a horizontal midline, or they cross at a midpoint.
  • Questions might ask:
    • "When Variable A was at its highest
    • what was Variable B?" For mirror-image inverse trends
    • the answer is that B was at its lowest. This type of inverse trend indicates a strong complementary relationship
    • often due to conservation laws (percentages must sum to 100%
    • mass is conserved
    • energy is conserved

Recognizing mirror-image patterns helps you make accurate predictions about one variable based on the other.

Partial Inverse Trends

  • Pattern: Variables might be inversely related under some conditions but not others.
  • Example: Temperature and dissolved oxygen in water are inversely related (higher temperature → lower dissolved O₂) but only up to a point. Once O₂ reaches zero, it can't decrease further even if temperature continues increasing.
  • Graphically: Lines might slope in opposite directions for part of the x-range, then one line levels off while the other continues changing.
  • Questions might ask: "Over what range were the variables inversely related?" You need to identify the specific x-range where the inverse pattern holds

Don't assume inverse relationships continue indefinitely—look at the actual data to see where the pattern applies. Physical limitations (can't go below zero, can't exceed 100%, saturation limits, etc.) often cause partial inverse trends where the relationship breaks down at extremes.

Delayed or Lagged Inverse Responses

  • Pattern:
    • When one variable changes, the other doesn't immediately respond inversely
    • there's a time lag
  • Example:
    • In a predator-prey relationship, when prey population decreases, predator population doesn't immediately decrease
    • it takes time for predators to starve and die off. The inverse relationship exists but with a delay
  • Graphically: The peak of one variable might occur slightly later than the trough of another

The lines don't cross at the same x-value they would if the response were immediate. (4) Questions might ask: "How much time elapsed between the minimum of Variable A and the maximum of Variable B?" You need to find the x-value where A is minimum and the x-value where B is maximum, then calculate the difference. Delayed inverse responses are common in biological and ecological systems where responses take time to manifest

Recognizing this pattern prevents you from incorrectly concluding that variables aren't inversely related just because the timing isn't perfect.

Inverse Relationships with Different Rates of Change

  • Pattern:
    • As X increases
    • Y consistently decreases
    • but the magnitude of Y's decrease doesn't equal the magnitude of X's increase
  • Example:
    • Altitude and air pressure are inversely related, but pressure doesn't decrease linearly with altitude
    • it decreases exponentially. A 1000 m increase in altitude causes a bigger pressure drop at low altitudes than at high altitudes
  • Graphically: One line might be straight while the other is curved, or both might be curved with different curvatures

They're still inverse (opposite directions) but the relationship isn't a simple 1:1 mirror. (4) Questions might ask: "As X doubled from 10 to 20, Y decreased by what percentage?" You need to read specific values and calculate the change, not assume equal magnitudes. Understanding that inverse relationships don't require equal-magnitude changes helps you recognize a wider range of inverse patterns and avoid incorrectly concluding that variables aren't inversely related just because their rates of change differ.

  • Mirror-Image:
    • : Graph shows % Component A and % Component B in a mixture over time A increases from 40% to 60% (+20%) B decreases from 60% to 40% (-20%) Perfect mirror
    • they must sum to 100% at all times
  • Partial Inverse:: Temperature increases from 0°C to 100°C Dissolved O₂ decreases from 15 mg/L to 0 mg/L (from 0-60°C)
  • then stays at 0 (from 60-100°C) Inverse relationship exists from 0-60°C, but not beyond 60°C because O₂ can't go negative
  • Delayed Response:: Prey population reaches minimum at t=20 months Predator population reaches maximum at t=24 months (4-month delay) Still inversely related, but with a time lag
  • Different Rates:
    • : As pressure doubles from 1 to 2 atm, volume decreases from 100 L to 50 L As pressure doubles again from 2 to 4 atm, volume decreases from 50 L to 25 L Inverse relationship (pressure up → volume down) but the relationship is hyperbolic, not linear Each doubling of pressure halves volume
    • inverse but not equal-magnitude changes

4. Common Pitfalls and Strategic Approaches

Avoiding common errors and using strategic approaches maximizes accuracy on inverse trend and dual-axis questions.

Pitfall #1: Reading Values from the Wrong Axis

  • Why it happens:
    • Students identify the correct line and trace to a y-value
    • but read from whichever axis is nearest or most convenient
    • rather than the axis that corresponds to that variable
  • Result:
    • You get the other variable's value
    • leading to a wrong answer. For example
    • you need temperature but read pressure
  • Prevention: Always, always verify which axis matches your variable before reading

Check units, check labels, check the legend. Make this verification a non-negotiable step. (4) Slow down

The 5 seconds you spend verifying the correct axis prevents a costly error that wastes the entire question. (5) Physical technique: Use your finger or pencil to trace from the data point horizontally to the correct axis, keeping your trace line straight and level to ensure you read from the right side. This pitfall is easily avoided with deliberate care but costs many students points due to rushing.

Pitfall #2: Confusing "Inverse" with "Opposite Values"

  • Inverse relationship means opposite directional changes (one increases while the other decreases), not that the values are opposites or negatives of each other.
  • Example of confusion: If Variable A = +5 and Variable B = +10, they're not inversely related just because the numbers are different. You need to look at how they change.
  • Correct understanding:
    • If A increases from 5 to 10 while B decreases from 20 to 15
    • then they're inversely related (both changed
    • but in opposite directions)
  • Prevention:
    • When asked about relationships
    • focus on trends and direction of change
    • not individual values

Look at slopes and patterns over the x-range, not single data points. (5) Answer choice clue: Inverse relationship answers will describe directional patterns: "as X increases, Y decreases" not "X and Y have opposite values". Understanding this terminology distinction prevents conceptual errors.

Strategy: Using Axis Colors and Line Colors

  • Match colors:
    • If the left axis label is blue and one line is blue
    • they go together. If the right axis is red and another line is red
    • they go together
  • If no colors, look for line styles (solid vs. dashed) that match axis styles, or look for explicit statements in the legend like "— Temperature (left axis)" and "--- Pressure (right axis)".
  • Create your own color-coding:
    • If the graph isn't color-coded and you're struggling to keep track
    • use your pencil to mark the left axis with one symbol (like an asterisk) and the right axis with another (like a plus sign)
    • then mark the corresponding lines with the same symbols
  • Benefit: Visual association is faster and more reliable than repeatedly reading labels

Once you've established which line goes with which axis, you can navigate the graph much more efficiently for all subsequent questions. This strategic use of visual cues significantly reduces errors and saves time.

Strategy: Describing Inverse Trends Correctly in Answer Choices

  • Direct statement: "Variables X and Y are inversely related" or "X and Y show an inverse relationship".
  • Directional description:
    • "As X increases
    • Y decreases" or "When X was highest
    • Y was lowest"
  • Negative correlation language: "X and Y are negatively correlated".
  • Indirect language: "Increasing X resulted in lower Y values". When selecting answers: Look for opposite-direction language

If your analysis shows one variable going up while another goes down, select answers that describe this opposition. Eliminate answers suggesting both move together ("both increase", "positive correlation", "directly related").

Be careful with "indirect" or "inverse" which are synonyms for negative correlation and opposite-direction relationships. Understanding how ACT phrases inverse relationships helps you recognize correct answers even when worded differently than you expected.

  • Pitfall 1 Prevention:: Question: "What was the temperature at t=40 min?" Dual-axis graph: Left axis (0-100°C), Right axis (0-5 atm) At t=40: Blue line (temperature) is at a height corresponding to both 60°C (left) and 3 atm (right) WRONG: Quickly read from right axis → 3 atm CORRECT: Verify temperature uses left axis → read from left → 60°C Prevention: Always verify which axis matches the variable before reading
  • Pitfall 2 Prevention:
    • : Question: "What is the relationship between X and Y?" Data: At t=0, X=10, Y=50
    • At t=30, X=30, Y=30
    • At t=60, X=50, Y=10 WRONG: "X and Y are opposites because 10≠50" (confusing values with relationship) CORRECT: "X and Y are inversely related because as X increases from 10 to 50, Y decreases from 50 to 10" (focusing on directional changes) Prevention: Analyze trends/changes, not just individual values
  • Strategy Application:: Use color-coding: Left axis and one line are blue → mark both with * mentally Right axis and other line are red → mark both with + mentally Now when reading temperature
  • think "blue line, blue axis" → left axis When reading pressure, think "red line, red axis" → right axis Visual association prevents axis confusion

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Inverse trends (negative correlations) occur when one variable increases while another decreases
  • ✓Dual-axis graphs use two y-axes (left and right) to show variables with different scales on the same plot
  • ✓Always verify which variable corresponds to which axis before reading values—use colors, legends, and units
  • ✓Inverse relationships mean opposite directional changes, not that values are opposites or negatives
  • ✓Mirror-image inverse trends show perfect complementary behavior (e.g., percentages summing to 100%)
  • ✓Some inverse relationships only exist in part of the data range due to physical limitations
  • ✓Variables can be inversely related even if they change at different rates or magnitudes
  • ✓Use color-coding and visual matching to associate lines with their correct axes on dual-axis graphs
  • ✓For comparison questions, focus on line directions (up, down, flat) rather than absolute values
  • ✓Reading from the wrong axis is the most common error—always trace horizontally to the correct y-axis

title: Topic 2.5 - Adding or Deleting Information
content:
Adding or deleting information questions test your ability to evaluate whether a sentence or phrase belongs in a passage, requiring you to assess relevance, redundancy, and logical flow. These questions ask "Should the writer add this sentence?" or "Should the writer delete the underlined portion?" and require you to understand the paragraph's main idea and determine whether the proposed addition or deletion strengthens or weakens the passage. Answering correctly requires not just deciding yes or no, but selecting the reason that best explains your decision.

1. Understanding Adding/Deleting Questions

Question Format and Structure

Adding/deleting questions follow a predictable format that requires a two-part answer:

Adding questions: Present a sentence in a box or brackets and ask: "Should the writer make this addition here?"

  • Choices A and B answer "Yes" with different reasons
  • Choices C and D answer "No" with different reasons
  • You must decide both whether to add AND which reason is correct

Deleting questions: Underline a portion of text and ask: "Should the writer delete the underlined portion?"

  • Choices F and G answer "Yes, because" with different reasons
  • Choices H and J answer "No, because" with different reasons
  • Again, you must decide both whether to delete AND which reason is correct

Example format:

[The team spent three months analyzing data from over 500 participants.]

Should the writer make this addition here?

A. Yes, because it provides specific information about the scope of the research.
B. Yes, because it explains why the research took so long to complete.
C. No, because it repeats information already provided earlier in the paragraph.
D. No, because it distracts from the paragraph's focus on the research findings.

The Two-Step Decision Process

Approach these questions systematically with two separate decisions:

Step 1: Should the information be added/kept or not?

  • Read the proposed addition or underlined deletion carefully
  • Consider whether it's relevant to the paragraph's main idea
  • Determine if it adds value or creates problems (redundancy, distraction)
  • This narrows your choices to two options (either both "Yes" or both "No")

Step 2: Which reason is accurate?

  • Compare the two remaining reasons carefully
  • One reason will be factually accurate, the other will contain an error
  • Check each reason against the actual content and context
  • Select the reason that correctly describes the situation

Reading Context Carefully

To answer these questions accurately, you must understand:

  • The paragraph's main idea: What is this paragraph primarily about?
  • What precedes and follows: Read 2-3 sentences before and after the proposed addition/deletion
  • The paragraph's purpose: Is it describing, explaining, arguing, narrating?
  • Information already provided: Watch for redundancy with nearby sentences

This context determines whether the information is relevant and necessary or whether it should be excluded.

2. Evaluating Additions

When to Add Information

Add the proposed sentence when it:

Provides relevant, specific support: The addition offers concrete details, evidence, or examples that directly relate to and strengthen the paragraph's main idea.

Context: A paragraph describes how Dr. Chen developed a new surgical technique.

Proposed addition: [This technique reduced average recovery time from six weeks to just ten days.]

Should add: Yes, because it provides specific, measurable evidence of the technique's benefit, directly supporting the paragraph's discussion of Dr. Chen's innovation.

Clarifies or explains necessary information: The addition helps readers understand complex ideas or processes described in the paragraph.

Provides essential context: The addition supplies background information needed to understand the paragraph's main points.

Creates necessary transitions: The addition logically connects ideas that would otherwise seem disconnected.

When NOT to Add Information

Do NOT add the proposed sentence when it:

Repeats information already stated: The most common reason to reject an addition is redundancy—if the information is already conveyed elsewhere in the paragraph, adding it creates unnecessary repetition.

Context: Previous sentence states: "The museum houses over 10,000 artifacts from ancient Egypt."

Proposed addition: [The museum's collection includes thousands of items from Egyptian civilization.]

Should NOT add: No, because it repeats information that was already clearly stated in the previous sentence.

Goes off-topic or distracts: The addition may be interesting or even true, but if it doesn't directly support the paragraph's main idea, it's a distraction.

Context: A paragraph focuses on how architect Maya Lin designed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial to honor fallen soldiers.

Proposed addition: [Lin also designed the Civil Rights Memorial in Montgomery, Alabama.]

Should NOT add: No, because while true, it shifts focus from the Vietnam Veterans Memorial (the paragraph's topic) to a different project.

Contradicts or confuses: The addition creates logical inconsistencies or makes the passage harder to understand.

Provides irrelevant detail: The information is too specific, technical, or tangential for the passage's scope and audience.

Evaluating the Reasons

Once you've decided whether to add or not, carefully evaluate which reason is accurate:

Check factual accuracy: Does the reason correctly describe what the proposed addition actually does? For example, if the reason says "it provides statistical evidence" but the addition doesn't contain statistics, that reason is wrong.

Verify the claim: If the reason says "it repeats information from earlier," check whether that information truly appears earlier. If it doesn't, that reason is incorrect even if you've decided not to add the sentence.

Assess relevance claims: If a reason says the addition is relevant or irrelevant to the paragraph's focus, verify this against the paragraph's actual main idea.

Example: A paragraph discusses the economic impact of a new factory.

Proposed addition: [The factory created 500 new jobs in the community.]

A. Yes, because it provides specific evidence of the factory's economic impact.
B. Yes, because it explains the factory's manufacturing process.
C. No, because this information appears earlier in the essay.
D. No, because it distracts from the paragraph's focus on environmental concerns.

Analysis: The addition should be made because it provides relevant, specific evidence. Between A and B, only A is factually accurate—the sentence discusses jobs (economic impact), not manufacturing process.

Answer: A

3. Evaluating Deletions

When to Delete Information

Delete the underlined portion when it:

Repeats information unnecessarily: The most common valid reason for deletion is redundancy. If the same information is clearly stated elsewhere, the redundant portion should be deleted.

Example: "The ancient temple, which was built in ancient times, features intricate carvings."

Should delete: Yes, because "ancient" already indicates the temple was built long ago, making "which was built in ancient times" redundant.

Goes off-topic: The underlined portion introduces information unrelated to the paragraph's main focus, distracting from the central idea.

Creates wordiness without adding value: The underlined portion uses many words to say what could be said more concisely, or adds no meaningful information.

Contradicts other information: The underlined portion conflicts with facts or ideas presented elsewhere in the passage.

When NOT to Delete Information

Keep the underlined portion when it:

Provides necessary detail or support: The underlined portion offers specific information, evidence, or examples that strengthen the paragraph's main idea.

Context: A paragraph discusses an athlete's dedication to training.

Sentence: "She practiced six hours daily, including two hours of strength training and four hours perfecting technique."

Should NOT delete underlined portion: No, because the specific breakdown of how the six hours were spent (strength training vs. technique) provides valuable detail that illustrates her comprehensive training approach.

Creates necessary connections: The underlined portion provides transitions, explanations, or context needed for logical flow.

Offers relevant elaboration: The underlined portion expands on an idea in a way that enhances understanding without being redundant.

Maintains the sentence's core meaning: Deleting the portion would remove essential information or make the sentence unclear or incomplete.

Common Deletion Question Traps

Be aware of these common patterns in wrong answers:

Incorrect redundancy claims: A reason might claim something is redundant when it actually provides new, specific information that builds on (rather than repeats) earlier content.

Example: Previous sentence says "The river is polluted." Next sentence says "Chemical runoff from three nearby factories has contaminated the water with mercury and lead."

Wrong reason: "Yes, delete because this information is already stated in the previous sentence."

Why it's wrong: The second sentence doesn't repeat that the river is polluted—it provides specific details about the source (factories) and type (mercury, lead) of pollution. This is elaboration, not redundancy.

Misidentifying relevance: A reason might claim the information is off-topic when it actually relates directly to the paragraph's focus, or vice versa.

Overstating importance: A reason might claim the information is "essential" or "necessary" when it's actually just mildly relevant or tangential.

Mischaracterizing content: A reason might claim the underlined portion "explains the process" when it actually provides an example, or "gives historical background" when it discusses current applications.

4. Strategic Approach and Practice

Systematic Method

Follow this step-by-step approach for all adding/deleting questions:

Step 1: Read the surrounding context. Read 2-3 sentences before and after to understand the paragraph's main idea and how ideas flow.

Step 2: Identify the paragraph's focus. Ask yourself: "What is this paragraph primarily about?" This helps you judge relevance.

Step 3: Read the proposed addition or underlined deletion. Understand exactly what information would be added or removed.

Step 4: Make your add/delete decision. Ask:

  • Is this information relevant to the paragraph's main idea?
  • Does it add new, valuable information or repeat what's already stated?
  • Does it strengthen the passage or distract from its focus?

This eliminates two answer choices, leaving you with two options.

Step 5: Evaluate the two remaining reasons. Check each reason against the actual content:

  • Is the reason factually accurate about what the addition/deletion does?
  • Does it correctly identify why the information should or shouldn't be included?
  • Does it match the paragraph's actual focus and existing content?

Step 6: Select the answer with the correct reason. Even if both reasons seem plausible, one will be more accurate. Choose the one that best describes the actual situation.

Distinguishing Redundancy from Elaboration

One of the trickiest aspects of these questions is differentiating between redundancy (which should be deleted or not added) and elaboration (which adds value):

Redundancy: Repeating the same information in different words without adding new details or insights.

Example: "The building is tall. The structure rises high into the air." (Second sentence adds no new information) Elaboration: Building on a general statement with specific details, examples, or explanations.

Example: "The building is tall. At 75 stories, it dominates the city skyline and can be seen from 20 miles away." (Second sentence provides specific details that support and expand the first)

Key distinction: Elaboration provides new information (how many stories, how far visible, impact on skyline) while redundancy just restates the same idea (tall = rises high).

Time Management

Adding/deleting questions require more reading than typical grammar questions but should still be answered efficiently:

  • Budget 45-60 seconds: You need time to read context and evaluate reasons, but don't exceed one minute
  • Focus your reading: You don't need the entire passage—just 2-3 sentences of context around the addition/deletion
  • Decide add/delete first: This immediately eliminates half the choices, making reason evaluation more efficient
  • Trust clear evidence: If one reason contains a factual error or mischaracterization, eliminate it confidently

Practice with Complete Examples

Example 1 (Addition):

Context: Maria Rodriguez transformed urban farming in Chicago by converting vacant lots into productive gardens. She began with a single plot in 2005 and now oversees 47 community gardens across the city.

Proposed addition: [These gardens produce over 50,000 pounds of fresh vegetables annually, providing food for more than 2,000 families.]

At this point, the writer is considering adding the following sentence. Should the writer make this addition here?

F. Yes, because it provides specific data that demonstrates the scale and impact of Rodriguez's work.
G. Yes, because it explains the agricultural techniques Rodriguez uses in the gardens.
H. No, because it contradicts information presented earlier about the number of gardens.
J. No, because it distracts from the paragraph's focus on Rodriguez's background and education.

Analysis:
Step 1: Should we add this? Yes—the addition provides specific, relevant evidence about the impact of the gardens described in the previous sentence.
Step 2: This eliminates H and J. Between F and G, which is accurate?
- F correctly identifies that the sentence provides specific data (50,000 pounds, 2,000 families) showing scale and impact
- G is wrong—the sentence doesn't explain agricultural techniques; it provides outcome data

Answer: F

Example 2 (Deletion):

Context: The volcano's eruption lasted six hours. During this time, lava flows destroyed 200 homes and displaced 3,000 residents, while ash clouds disrupted air travel across the entire region.

The writer is considering deleting the underlined portion. Should the writer make this deletion?

A. Yes, because this information is already stated earlier in the paragraph.
B. Yes, because it distracts from the paragraph's focus on the volcano's geological history.
C. No, because it provides specific examples of the eruption's impact on the community.
D. No, because it explains why the eruption lasted six hours.

Analysis:
Step 1: Should we delete this? No—the underlined portion provides specific, relevant details about the eruption's impact.
Step 2: This eliminates A and B. Between C and D, which is accurate?
- C correctly identifies that the sentence provides specific examples of impact (homes destroyed, residents displaced, air travel disrupted)
- D is wrong—the sentence doesn't explain why the eruption lasted six hours; it describes what happened during those six hours

Answer: C

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Adding/deleting questions require a two-part answer: decide whether to add/keep or delete/reject, then select the accurate reason
  • ✓Make your add/delete decision first to eliminate half the answer choices immediately
  • ✓Read 2-3 sentences before and after the proposed addition/deletion to understand the paragraph's main idea and context
  • ✓Add information when it provides relevant, specific support for the paragraph's main idea; don't add when it's redundant, off-topic, or distracting
  • ✓Delete information when it repeats what's already stated, goes off-topic, or adds no value; keep it when it provides necessary detail or creates logical connections
  • ✓Distinguish between redundancy (repeating the same information) and elaboration (providing specific details that build on general statements)
  • ✓Evaluate reasons carefully for factual accuracy—check whether they correctly describe what the addition/deletion actually does
  • ✓Watch for wrong reasons that mischaracterize content, incorrectly claim redundancy when information is new, or misjudge relevance to the paragraph's focus
  • ✓Even if you're unsure about add/delete, you can often identify one reason as clearly wrong due to factual errors or mischaracterizations
  • ✓Budget 45-60 seconds per question—these require more context reading but should not exceed one minute

title: Topic 3.5 - Math on the Science Test
content:
Math-on-science questions test your ability to perform calculations using scientific data, apply mathematical formulas in scientific contexts, convert between units and scales, and manipulate numerical information from tables and graphs. Unlike pure data reading questions, these require actual computation—calculating averages, percentages, rates, ratios, or applying given formulas with values from the passage.

This lesson teaches you efficient calculation strategies for common ACT science math scenarios, explains how to extract and organize numerical data before computing, provides techniques for managing units and conversions, and shows you how to estimate and check answers to avoid calculation errors under time pressure.

1. Common Calculation Types in ACT Science

Understanding the types of calculations that frequently appear helps you recognize what's being asked and select the right approach quickly.

Averages, Means, and Totals

  • Mean (arithmetic average):
    • Sum all values and divide by the count. If three trials gave 12
    • the mean is (12 + 15 + 18)/3 = 45/3 = 15
  • Finding totals: Sometimes questions ask for the sum across conditions

If Trial 1 produced 5 g, Trial 2 produced 8 g, and Trial 3 produced 7 g, the total is 20 g. (3) Weighted averages: Occasionally, different values should contribute differently to the average based on their frequency or importance. If 60% of samples measured 10 and 40% measured 15, the weighted average is (0.6×10) + (0.4×15) = 6 + 6 = 12. (4) Common errors: Make sure you count the number of values correctly

If a table shows 5 rows of data, the average divides by 5, not 4. Also, be clear on what to average—sometimes it's raw values, sometimes it's calculated values from each trial.

The question "What was the average growth rate across the three conditions?" means calculate growth rate for each condition, then average those three rates.

Percentages, Ratios, and Proportions

Percentage questions ask you to express relationships as percents: (1) Percent of total: (Part/Whole) × 100%. If 15 out of 60 plants survived, the survival rate is (15/60) × 100% = 25%. (2) Percent change: [(New - Old)/Old] × 100%.

  • Ratios: Express as a fraction or simplified form. If 20 mL of A reacts with 30 mL of B, the ratio is 20:30 = 2:3.
  • Proportions: If the ratio of X to Y is 3:5 and there are 15 units of X, then Y = (5/3) × 15 = 25 units.
  • Common errors: For percent change, make sure "Old" is in the denominator

A change from 100 to 150 is +50%, but a change from 150 to 100 is -33.3% (not -50%). Also, when finding percent of total, ensure you're dividing by the correct total—sometimes it's a subtotal, not the grand total.

Rates, Slopes, and Change Over Time

  • Rate = Change / Time: If a plant grew from 5 cm to 20 cm in 3 days, the growth rate is (20-5)/3 = 5 cm/day.
  • Slope calculation from graphs: Slope = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁). Choose two clear points on a line

If (0, 10) and (5, 30) are on the line, slope = (30-10)/(5-0) = 20/5 = 4. The units are y-units per x-unit. (3) Rate units: Pay attention to units

Miles per hour, grams per second, degrees per minute—the denominator tells you the "per what" part. (4) Average rate vs. instantaneous rate: ACT questions typically ask for average rates over an interval. If speed was 40 mph for the first hour and 60 mph for the second hour, the average is 50 mph (assuming equal time intervals). (5) Negative rates: A decrease gives a negative rate

If temperature drops from 80°C to 50°C in 10 minutes, the rate is (50-80)/10 = -3°C/min. The negative sign indicates decrease.

Rates are fundamental to science—velocity, reaction rate, cooling rate, growth rate, etc.

Applying Given Formulas with Data

Many questions provide a formula and ask you to calculate using passage data: (1) Identify variables: Match each variable in the formula to a value from the passage. The passage might say "pressure (P) was 2 atm, volume (V) was 5 L, and temperature (T) was 300 K" and give you PV = nRT.

Identify that P = 2, V = 5, T = 300, R = 0.082 (given), and solve for n. (2) Substitute carefully: Write out the formula, substitute numbers with units, then calculate. This prevents mixing up variables. (3) Rearrange if needed: If the formula is given as y = 2x + 3 and you need to find x when y = 15, rearrange: 15 = 2x + 3 → 12 = 2x → x = 6. (4) Check units: After calculating, verify units make sense

If calculating speed and getting "5 meters," that's wrong—speed needs distance/time units. (5) Common formulas: Density = mass/volume, Speed = distance/time, Concentration = moles/volume. Even if not explicitly given, you're expected to know these basic relationships.

Formula questions are straightforward if you substitute correctly and perform arithmetic carefully.

  • Average:
    • : Three trials measured pH values of 6.2
    • and 7.0 Average pH = (6.2 + 6.8 + 7.0)/3 = 20.0/3 = 6.67
  • Percentage:: 24 out of 80 seeds germinated Percent germination = (24/80) × 100% = 0.3 × 100% = 30%
  • Percent change:: Mass increased from 50 g to 72 g Percent increase = [(72-50)/50] × 100% = (22/50) × 100% = 44%
  • Rate:: Object moved 120 meters in 15 seconds Speed = 120 m / 15 s = 8 m/s
  • Slope:
    • : Graph shows points (2
    • 30) Slope = (30-10)/(6-2) = 20/4 = 5 (units: y per x)
  • Formula application:
    • : Density = mass/volume
    • mass = 45 g
    • volume = 15 mL Density = 45/15 = 3 g/mL

2. Unit Conversions and Scale Manipulations

Many ACT science calculations require converting between units or working across different measurement scales.

Metric System Conversions

  • Common prefixes:
    • kilo (k) = 10³ = 1000
    • centi (c) = 10⁻² = 0.01
    • milli (m) = 10⁻³ = 0.001
    • micro (μ) = 10⁻⁶ = 0.000001
    • nano (n) = 10⁻⁹
  • Conversion method: Multiply by the conversion factor. To convert 3.5 km to meters: 3.5 km × 1000 m/km = 3500 m

To convert 250 mg to grams: 250 mg × 0.001 g/mg = 0.25 g. (3) Direction trick: From larger units to smaller units, multiply. From smaller to larger, divide. 5 kg to grams (larger to smaller): 5 × 1000 = 5000 g. 800 mL to liters (smaller to larger): 800 ÷ 1000 = 0.8 L. (4) Common conversions: 1 km = 1000 m, 1 m = 100 cm = 1000 mm, 1 L = 1000 mL, 1 g = 1000 mg, 1 kg = 1000 g. (5) Scientific notation: 1 km = 10³ m, 1 mg = 10⁻³ g

This helps with very large or small numbers. Metric conversions are straightforward if you know the prefixes and multiply by the right factor.

Temperature Scale Conversions

  • Celsius to Kelvin: K = °C + 273 (or more precisely, + 273.15). 25°C = 25 + 273 = 298 K.
  • Kelvin to Celsius: °C = K - 273. 350 K = 350 - 273 = 77°C.
  • Celsius to Fahrenheit: °F = (9/5)×°C + 32. 20°C = (9/5)×20 + 32 = 36 + 32 = 68°F.
  • Fahrenheit to Celsius: °C = (5/9)×(°F - 32). 86°F = (5/9)×(86-32) = (5/9)×54 = 30°C.
  • Key reference points: Water freezes at 0°C = 32°F = 273 K. Water boils at 100°C = 212°F = 373 K

Room temperature ≈ 20-25°C ≈ 68-77°F ≈ 293-298 K. (6) Temperature changes: A change of 1°C equals a change of 1 K (same size degree). But a change of 1°C equals a change of 1.8°F (different size degree).

For converting temperature differences (not absolute temperatures), ΔK = Δ°C and Δ°F = 1.8 × Δ°C. The ACT rarely requires Fahrenheit conversions but often uses Celsius and Kelvin interchangeably in science passages.

Compound Units and Dimensional Analysis

Compound units involve multiple dimensions: (1) Speed conversions: Convert m/s to km/h.

  • Density conversions: Convert g/mL to kg/L. 1.5 g/mL = 1.5 g/mL × (1 kg/1000 g) × (1000 mL/1 L) = 1.5 × 1000/1000 = 1.5 kg/L. Actually, g/mL = kg/L directly (1 g/mL = 1 kg/L).
  • Dimensional analysis method: Set up conversions so units cancel

To convert 50 mg/dL to g/L: 50 mg/dL × (1 g/1000 mg) × (10 dL/1 L) = 50 × 10/1000 g/L = 0.5 g/L. (4) Area and volume conversions: When squaring or cubing, apply the conversion factor to each dimension. 1 m² = (100 cm)² = 10,000 cm². 1 m³ = (100 cm)³ = 1,000,000 cm³. (5) Strategy: Write out units explicitly during conversions. If units don't cancel to give the desired result, you've set up the conversion incorrectly

The ACT tests whether you can correctly chain conversion factors to get from one unit system to another.

Scientific Notation and Order of Magnitude

  • Format:
    • a × 10ⁿ where 1 ≤ a < 10 and n is an integer. 3
    • 000 = 3.5 × 10⁶. 0.00042 = 4.2 × 10⁻⁴
  • Multiplication: Multiply the coefficients and add the exponents. (2 × 10³) × (3 × 10⁵) = 6 × 10⁸.
  • Division: Divide coefficients and subtract exponents. (8 × 10⁷) ÷ (2 × 10³) = 4 × 10⁴.
  • Addition/subtraction:
    • Convert to the same exponent first. (3 × 10⁴) + (2 × 10³) = (3 × 10⁴) + (0.2 × 10⁴) = 3.2 × 10⁴. Or convert: 30
    • 000 = 3.2 × 10⁴
  • Order of magnitude:
    • The exponent indicates the scale. 10⁶ is a million
    • 10⁹ is a billion
    • 10⁻⁹ is a billionth (nano)

Comparing orders of magnitude helps estimate: 5 × 10⁷ is about 50 million, much larger than 3 × 10⁴ (thirty thousand). (6) ACT usage: Scientific notation appears in astronomy (distances), microbiology (cell sizes), chemistry (molecular quantities). You need to compare, add, or convert these numbers confidently.

  • Metric:: Convert 2.5 km to meters 2.5 km × 1000 m/km = 2500 m
  • Temperature:: Convert 37°C to Kelvin K = 37 + 273 = 310 K
  • Temperature difference:: Temperature rose from 20°C to 45°C. What is the change in Kelvin? ΔT = 45 - 20 = 25°C = 25 K (same magnitude for temperature changes)
  • Compound units:: Convert 15 m/s to km/h 15 m/s × (1 km/1000 m) × (3600 s/1 h) = 15 × 3.6 km/h = 54 km/h
  • Scientific notation:: Multiply (4 × 10⁵) × (3 × 10⁻²) = (4 × 3) × (10⁵ × 10⁻²) = 12 × 10³ = 1.2 × 10⁴
  • Density conversion:: 2.7 g/cm³ to kg/m³ 2.7 g/cm³ × (1 kg/1000 g) × (10⁶ cm³/1 m³) = 2.7 × 1000 kg/m³ = 2700 kg/m³

3. Extracting and Organizing Data for Calculations

Before calculating, you must accurately locate and extract the necessary numerical information from complex tables, graphs, and text.

Reading Values from Tables Accurately

  • Identify row and column headers: Understand what each row and column represents. Headers often include units.
  • Trace carefully: Use your finger or pencil to trace from the row label to the column label, finding the intersection
  • Watch for units in headers:
    • If the column header says "Mass (g)", all values in that column are in grams
    • don't add "g" again or convert unnecessarily
  • Multi-level headers: Some tables have grouped columns. Make sure you're reading from the correct sub-column under the main category.
  • Missing or unclear values:
    • If a cell says "
    • " or is blank, it typically means no data or not applicable

Don't assume it's zero. (6) Common error: Reading the wrong row or column due to rushing. Double-check you're on the correct line, especially in dense tables with many rows.

Extracting Values from Graphs for Calculations

Graph reading for math questions: (1) Read axis scales carefully: Check the increment size. If gridlines are every 10 units and a point is 3 gridlines up, that's 30 units, not 3. (2) Estimate when necessary: If a point falls between gridlines, estimate its value

Between 40 and 50, halfway would be 45. Don't worry about extreme precision—ACT answer choices have enough separation. (3) For slope calculations, choose convenient points: Pick points on gridline intersections for easier reading.

Avoid points that require estimation unless necessary. (4) For areas under curves or bar heights: Use the scale to convert visual height to numerical value. A bar reaching the "60" line represents a value of 60 (in whatever units the axis shows). (5) Multiple data series: Make sure you're reading the correct line or bar set if the graph shows multiple variables

Check the legend. (6) Units: The axis label includes units. If y-axis says "Speed (m/s)", the value 20 means 20 m/s

Include units in your calculation setup.

Organizing Information Before Calculating

  • List known values with units:
    • Before plugging into a formula
    • write out what you know. "Mass = 25 g
    • Volume = 5 mL
    • Density = ?" This clarifies what you're solving for
  • Write the formula or calculation method: State the relationship. "Density = Mass/Volume". Then substitute: "Density = 25 g / 5 mL = 5 g/mL".
  • Keep units throughout: Include units at each step
  • For multi-step calculations, work sequentially:
    • Calculate intermediate values first. If finding average rate and you need to calculate individual rates first
    • do those calculations
    • write down results
    • then average
  • Use scratch space efficiently: The ACT provides scratch paper

Don't try to do complex calculations mentally. Write out steps to avoid arithmetic mistakes.

Organized work is faster and more accurate than rushing through mentally.

Dealing with Data Presented in Text

  • Underline or circle numbers as you read:
    • "The reaction occurred at 75°C and produced 3.2 grams of product in 15 minutes." Mark 75
    • and 15 so you can find them quickly when calculating
  • Note units immediately:
    • As you mark numbers
    • note their units. "75°C"
    • "15 min". This prevents confusion later
  • Watch for multiple values of the same variable: "Trial 1 used 10 mL while Trial 2 used 25 mL." Make sure you're using the correct value for the trial in question.
  • Definitions and given values: "Let R = 8.314 J/(mol·K)" or "The specific heat of aluminum is 0.9 J/(g·°C)" provides constants

Note these for later use. (5) Calculated vs. measured: Sometimes text says "the calculated value was X" versus "the measured value was Y". Make sure you use the right one for the question being asked.

Reading data from text requires active engagement—marking and annotating prevents missing crucial numbers.

  • Scenario:: A table shows Temperature (°C) in column 1 and Volume (mL) in column 2
  • At 25°C, volume is 150 mL. At 75°C, volume is 200 mL. Calculate the average rate of volume change per degree Celsius.
  • Step 1 - Extract data:
    • : Initial: T₁ = 25°C
    • V₁ = 150 mL Final: T₂ = 75°C
    • V₂ = 200 mL
  • Step 2 - Calculate changes:: ΔT = 75 - 25 = 50°C ΔV = 200 - 150 = 50 mL
  • Step 3 - Calculate rate:: Rate = ΔV / ΔT = 50 mL / 50°C = 1 mL/°C
  • Step 4 - Verify:: Units are correct (mL per °C = volume change per temperature change ✓) Rate is positive (volume increased as temperature increased ✓)
  • Answer:: The average rate of volume change is 1 mL/°C

4. Estimation, Checking, and Avoiding Calculation Errors

Under time pressure, you need strategies to calculate efficiently, estimate when appropriate, and catch errors before selecting answers.

Using Estimation to Narrow Answer Choices

Estimation can eliminate wrong answers quickly: (1) Round numbers for mental math: If calculating 48.7 × 3.1, round to 50 × 3 = 150. This estimates the answer is around 150 (actual: 151.0).

If answer choices are 15, 150, 1500, 15000, you know it's 150. (2) Order of magnitude check: Is the answer in the tens, hundreds, thousands? This eliminates wildly wrong choices. If calculating 0.003 × 500, estimate 0.003 ≈ 0.005 and 0.005 × 500 = 2.5

Actual is 1.5, so order of magnitude is "ones". Eliminate any answer in tens or tenths. (3) Percentage estimation: 17 out of 78 is close to 20 out of 80 = 20/80 = 25%.

Actual is 21.8%, but 25% is close enough to eliminate choices like 12% or 45%. (4) Ratio reasoning: If calculating a fraction, determine if it's close to 0, close to 1, or in between. 495/510 is very close to 1 (both numbers nearly equal). 12/487 is very close to 0 (tiny numerator). Use this to eliminate unreasonable answers. (5) When to estimate vs. calculate exactly: If answer choices are far apart (e.g., 2, 20, 200, 2000), estimation suffices

If they're close (e.g., 3.2, 3.5, 3.8, 4.1), calculate precisely.

Common Calculation Errors and How to Avoid Them

Frequent mistakes and prevention: (1) Arithmetic errors: Misadding, wrong multiplication, incorrect division. Prevention: Write out calculations clearly.

Double-check mental math for multi-digit numbers. (2) Order of operations: Calculate 5 + 3 × 4 as 17 (not 32). Remember PEMDAS: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division (left to right), Addition/Subtraction (left to right). (3) Sign errors: Subtracting a negative becomes addition. 10 - (-3) = 13

Or calculating percent decrease: use (New - Old)/Old, which gives a negative percent for decreases. (4) Decimal point placement: 0.5 × 6 = 3.0 (not 30 or 0.3). Count decimal places: 0.5 (one place) × 6 (zero places) = product has one decimal place. (5) Unit errors: Forgetting to convert units before calculating

If mass is in kg and volume in mL, convert one so both use compatible units. (6) Formula inversion: Using speed = time/distance instead of speed = distance/time. Write formulas clearly before substituting. (7) Prevention strategy: Work systematically, write steps, and use estimation to verify your calculated answer is in the right ballpark.

Reasonableness Checks After Calculating

  • Unit check:
    • Does the answer have the expected units? If calculating speed
    • is the answer in distance/time units? If you got "5 meters" for speed
    • that's wrong
  • Magnitude check:
    • Is the size reasonable? If calculating the average height of plants and getting 500 cm (5 meters), that's suspiciously tall for most plants
    • recheck the calculation
  • Comparison to data:
    • Is the calculated value consistent with the data? If averaging 10
    • and you get 25
    • that's impossible (average must be between 10 and 14)
  • Sign check:
    • If something decreased
    • the change should be negative. If temperature dropped from 80 to 60 and you calculated +20°C change
    • you have the sign wrong
  • Extreme value check:
    • If calculating a percentage and getting 350%
    • ask: is it possible for the value to be more than 100% of something? (Sometimes yes
    • like 350% increase
    • but if calculating "percentage of total"
    • it can't exceed 100%)
  • Quick re-calculation: If time allows and the answer seems odd, recalculate using a different method or double-check arithmetic

These sanity checks catch errors before you commit to an answer.

Strategic Calculator Use (If Allowed)

  • Know your calculator:
    • Be familiar with its functions before test day. Practice operations you'll need: basic arithmetic
    • scientific notation
    • perhaps square roots
  • Enter carefully: Double-check what you're entering

Use parentheses to ensure correct order of operations.

  • as (48+52)÷10, not 48+52÷10 (which would be 48 + 5.2).
  • Don't over-rely on it: Simple calculations (like 50/10 = 5) are faster mentally than typing into a calculator

Save calculator for complex operations (like 147.3/23.5 or 6.7²). (4) Scientific notation: Learn how to enter and interpret scientific notation on your calculator. Entering 3.2 × 10⁷ might require specific button sequences (often "3.2 EE 7" or "3.2 E 7"). (5) Check the display: Make sure the calculator shows what you think you entered before hitting equals. (6) Round appropriately: Calculators give many decimal places

Round to match answer choice precision. If choices are 3.1, 3.4, 3.7, 4.0 and calculator shows 3.683, the answer is 3.7

Even with a calculator, understanding the concepts and setting up calculations correctly is essential—calculators do arithmetic but don't think for you.

  • Problem:: Calculate the average of 23.7, 28.3, and 31.2
  • Estimation:: Round to 24, 28, 31 → sum ≈ 83 → average ≈ 83/3 ≈ 27.7
  • Exact calculation:: (23.7 + 28.3 + 31.2)/3 = 83.2/3 = 27.73
  • Check:: Result 27.73 is between 23.7 and 31.2 ✓ (average must be within data range)
  • Answer choices:
    • : If choices are 17.7
    • select 27.7
  • Problem with error:: Student calculates percent increase from 40 to 50 Wrong approach: (50-40)/50 × 100% = 20% ✗ Correct: (50-40)/40 × 100% = 25% ✓
  • Error check:: 20% increase from 40 would give 40 × 1.20 = 48, not 50. So 20% is wrong.
  • Verification:: 25% increase from 40 gives 40 × 1.25 = 50 ✓
  • Unit check example:: Calculate density with mass = 45 g, volume = 15 cm³ Density = 45 g / 15 cm³ = 3 g/cm³
  • Check:: Units are mass/volume (g/cm³) ✓ Typical density values are 0.5-20 g/cm³ for common materials ✓ If accidentally calculated 45 × 15 = 675, units would be g·cm³ (nonsensical for density) ✗

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Common calculations include averages (sum/count), percentages (part/whole × 100%), percent change [(new-old)/old × 100%], rates (change/time), and formula applications
  • ✓Metric conversions: multiply by 1000 going from larger to smaller units (km→m), divide by 1000 going smaller to larger (mg→g)
  • ✓Temperature conversions: K = °C + 273; for temperature changes, ΔK = Δ°C (same magnitude)
  • ✓Compound units require dimensional analysis: set up conversions so unwanted units cancel, leaving desired units
  • ✓Extract data carefully from tables (align row/column correctly) and graphs (read scales accurately, estimate between gridlines)
  • ✓Organize before calculating: list known values with units, write formulas, then substitute systematically
  • ✓Use estimation to eliminate unreasonable answers: round numbers for mental math, check order of magnitude
  • ✓Avoid common errors: order of operations (PEMDAS), correct denominator in percent change, unit consistency, decimal placement
  • ✓Verify reasonableness: check units, magnitude, whether answer fits data range, sign (positive/negative) correctness
  • ✓Keep units throughout calculations to catch errors and ensure final answer has correct units for the quantity being calculated

title: Topic 2.6 - Logical Placement
content:
Logical placement questions test your ability to organize information effectively by determining where a sentence belongs within a paragraph or where a paragraph belongs within an essay. These questions require you to understand logical flow, recognize transitions, and identify how ideas build upon one another. Whether you're placing a sentence within a paragraph or reordering entire paragraphs, success depends on identifying chronological sequences, cause-effect relationships, and references that connect ideas.

1. Understanding Sentence Placement Questions

Question Format

Sentence placement questions present a sentence (usually in a box) and ask you to determine where it should be placed within a paragraph. The paragraph's sentences are numbered [1], [2], [3], [4], etc., and answer choices typically offer:

  • A. Where it is now (before sentence 1)
  • B. After sentence 1
  • C. After sentence 2
  • D. After sentence 3

You must determine which position creates the most logical flow of ideas.

Key Strategies for Sentence Placement

To place a sentence correctly, look for specific connections between the sentence and its context:

Identify references: Look for pronouns (it, they, this, that) or demonstrative phrases (this technique, these results) in the sentence you're placing. These references must have clear antecedents—the noun they refer to must appear in the preceding sentence.

Example:

Sentence to place: [This discovery changed how scientists understood the disease.]

Key question: What does "this discovery" refer to? It must be placed immediately after a sentence that describes a specific discovery.

If sentence 2 says "In 2010, researchers identified a genetic marker linked to the condition," then "this discovery" logically refers to the genetic marker identification. The sentence should be placed after sentence 2.

Follow chronological order: If the sentence describes an event, action, or step in a process, it must fit the time sequence established by surrounding sentences.

Match cause and effect: If the sentence describes a result or consequence, it must follow the sentence that presents the cause.

Recognize topic shifts: The sentence might introduce a new idea or conclude a discussion. Place it where the topic naturally transitions.

Reading for Context

Don't just read the sentence you're placing—carefully read the entire paragraph to understand:

  • The paragraph's organization: Is it chronological? Does it move from general to specific? From problem to solution?
  • What each numbered sentence discusses: Identify the main point of sentences 1, 2, 3, and 4
  • How ideas currently flow: Look for transitions and logical connections between existing sentences
  • Where gaps or transitions occur: The sentence you're placing often fills a logical gap or creates a necessary transition

This comprehensive understanding helps you identify where the new sentence naturally fits.

2. Analyzing References and Transitions

Pronouns and Demonstrative References

The most reliable clues for sentence placement are pronouns and demonstrative phrases that require clear antecedents:

Pronouns requiring antecedents:

  • It, they, them, these, those must refer to specific nouns in the preceding sentence
  • He, she, her, his must follow introduction of the person
  • The pronoun and its antecedent must agree in number (singular/plural)

Example:

Sentence to place: [She spent the next decade refining these techniques.]

Analysis: Two clues here:
1. "She" requires a female person to be introduced first
2. "These techniques" requires specific techniques to be mentioned immediately before

The sentence must be placed after a sentence that both introduces a female person and describes specific techniques she developed.

Demonstrative phrases:

  • "This method," "this approach," "this discovery" refer to something specific just mentioned
  • "Such techniques," "such results" point to examples or outcomes in the previous sentence
  • "That finding," "that conclusion" reference a specific claim or result

These phrases create strong dependencies—the sentence containing them MUST immediately follow the sentence that introduces what they reference.

Transition Words as Placement Clues

Transition words and phrases in the sentence you're placing reveal its logical relationship to surrounding sentences:

Continuation/Addition transitions (moreover, furthermore, additionally, also) indicate the sentence should follow related content, adding to the same idea.

Contrast transitions (however, nevertheless, yet, in contrast) signal the sentence presents an opposing or different idea from what precedes it.

Cause/Effect transitions (therefore, consequently, as a result, thus) show the sentence presents a result or conclusion and must follow the cause or premise.

Example:

Sentence to place: [As a result, the population declined by 40% in just five years.]

"As a result" signals this sentence presents a consequence. It must be placed after a sentence describing the cause of the population decline (such as habitat loss, disease, or environmental change).

If sentence 3 says "Pollution from the nearby factory poisoned the lake," then the population decline is a logical result of that pollution. Place the sentence after sentence 3.

Sequential transitions (first, next, then, finally) indicate position in a step-by-step process or chronological sequence.

Example/Illustration transitions (for example, for instance, specifically) show the sentence provides a concrete example and should follow a general statement.

Chronological and Sequential Clues

Many paragraphs follow a time-based order. Look for:

  • Dates and time markers: "In 2015," "After graduation," "During her childhood," "By the end of the decade"
  • Age or life stage references: "At age 12," "As a young adult," "In her later years"
  • Process steps: "Before mixing," "During fermentation," "After cooling"
  • Historical periods: "During the Renaissance," "In the post-war era"

The sentence you're placing must fit this chronological progression. If sentence 1 discusses the 1990s and sentence 2 discusses the 2010s, a sentence about events in 2005 logically fits between them.

Example:

[1] Chen began studying marine biology in college. [2] After earning her doctorate, she joined the research team at the Scripps Institution. [3] There, she made her groundbreaking discovery about coral reef resilience.

Sentence to place: [Her undergraduate thesis on tidal ecosystems earned recognition from the National Science Foundation.]

Analysis: "Undergraduate thesis" happens during college, which is mentioned in sentence 1. "After earning her doctorate" in sentence 2 comes later. Therefore, the sentence about her undergraduate work should be placed after sentence 1, before sentence 2.

Answer: After sentence 1

3. Understanding Paragraph Placement Questions

Question Format

Paragraph placement questions typically appear at the end of a passage and ask you to determine the most logical order for numbered paragraphs. The question format is:

"For the sake of logic and coherence, Paragraph 3 should be placed:"

  • F. where it is now.
  • G. after Paragraph 1.
  • H. after Paragraph 4.
  • J. after Paragraph 5.

These questions test your understanding of how entire paragraphs relate to one another and build the essay's argument or narrative.

Identifying Each Paragraph's Function

To reorder paragraphs effectively, identify what each paragraph does:

Introduction paragraphs:

  • Introduce the topic, person, or event
  • Provide essential background or context
  • Usually contain the essay's thesis or main idea
  • Should come first (or very early) in the essay

Development paragraphs:

  • Present evidence, examples, or details
  • Build on information from previous paragraphs
  • Often follow chronological or logical progression
  • May introduce new aspects of the topic

Conclusion paragraphs:

  • Summarize or reflect on what's been discussed
  • Present final outcomes or implications
  • May look to the future or broader significance
  • Should come last (or very late) in the essay

Looking for Dependencies Between Paragraphs

Certain paragraphs depend on others and cannot be placed before them:

References to previously mentioned information: If a paragraph begins with "This discovery" or "These efforts," it must follow the paragraph that introduces the discovery or efforts.

Chronological dependencies: A paragraph about "her later career" cannot come before paragraphs about her early life and education.

Logical progression: A paragraph describing results depends on earlier paragraphs explaining the experiment or process.

Example:

Paragraph 2: Discusses how Dr. Lopez developed a new vaccine in 2015
Paragraph 3: Begins with "Following this breakthrough, she received the Nobel Prize"

Analysis: "This breakthrough" in Paragraph 3 clearly refers to the vaccine development in Paragraph 2. Therefore, Paragraph 3 MUST come after Paragraph 2. Any answer choice that places Paragraph 3 before Paragraph 2 is automatically wrong.

Common Essay Organization Patterns

Recognizing these common patterns helps you determine logical paragraph order:

Chronological/Biographical: Follows a person's life or events over time—childhood, education, career, later achievements.

Problem-Solution: Introduces a problem, explains its causes or severity, presents solutions, describes outcomes.

General to Specific: Begins with broad context, narrows to specific examples, cases, or applications.

Cause and Effect: Presents a situation or cause, then explores various effects or consequences.

Process Description: Explains steps in order—preparation, execution, results, significance.

Identify which pattern the essay follows, then ensure paragraphs appear in the order that pattern requires.

4. Strategic Approach and Practice

Step-by-Step Method for Sentence Placement

Step 1: Read the sentence to be placed. Identify key clues:

  • Pronouns or demonstrative references (it, this, these, that)
  • Transition words (however, therefore, for example)
  • Time markers or chronological clues
  • Specific terms that need to be introduced first

Step 2: Read the entire paragraph. Understand the flow and identify what each numbered sentence discusses.

Step 3: Test each placement option. For each answer choice, mentally insert the sentence in that position and ask:

  • Do all references have clear antecedents?
  • Does the chronology make sense?
  • Do transitions work logically?
  • Does the sentence flow naturally in and out?

Step 4: Eliminate illogical placements. Often you can quickly eliminate 1-2 options that create obvious problems (references with no antecedents, chronological impossibilities).

Step 5: Choose the most natural fit. The correct placement creates smooth logical flow without forcing connections.

Step-by-Step Method for Paragraph Placement

Step 1: Identify the paragraph in question. Read it carefully and note:

  • Its main topic or purpose
  • Opening references or transitions
  • Chronological or logical markers
  • Dependencies on other information

Step 2: Skim all paragraphs. Get a sense of:

  • Which introduces the topic
  • The chronological or logical sequence
  • Which concludes the essay

Step 3: Look for strong dependencies. Identify any paragraph that clearly must come before or after the paragraph in question.

Step 4: Test each placement option. Consider whether each position creates logical flow or causes problems.

Step 5: Select the option that creates the most coherent progression. The correct placement follows the essay's organizational pattern and maintains all logical dependencies.

Time Management

Placement questions require careful reading but shouldn't consume excessive time:

  • Sentence placement: 45-60 seconds - Read the paragraph and test placement logically
  • Paragraph placement: 60-90 seconds - Requires skimming multiple paragraphs but clear dependencies often make the answer obvious
  • Use strong clues first: If you spot a clear pronoun reference or chronological marker, use it to quickly eliminate wrong answers
  • Don't overthink: The correct placement should feel natural; if you're forcing connections, you've likely chosen the wrong position

Complete Practice Example

Paragraph:

[1] The restoration project began in 2018 with a survey of the building's structural damage. [2] Workers carefully removed layers of old paint to reveal the original murals underneath. [3] By 2022, the historic theater had been transformed, returning to its 1920s grandeur. [4] Artisans spent months recreating decorative plasterwork that had deteriorated over the decades.

Sentence to place: [These murals, painted by renowned artist Diego Rivera, had been hidden for nearly 80 years.]

Question: For the sake of logic and coherence, this sentence should be placed:

A. where it is now (before sentence 1)
B. after sentence 1
C. after sentence 2
D. after sentence 3

Analysis:
Key clue: "These murals" is a demonstrative reference requiring an antecedent—murals must be mentioned immediately before this sentence.

Chronology check: The sentence provides additional detail about murals, not a time-sequenced step in the restoration.

Testing options:
- Before sentence 1: No prior mention of murals—"these murals" has no antecedent ❌
- After sentence 1: Sentence 1 discusses structural survey, not murals ❌
- After sentence 2: Sentence 2 mentions "the original murals"—"these murals" clearly refers to them ✓
- After sentence 3: This would separate the description of the murals from their discovery, disrupting flow ❌

The sentence provides elaboration about the murals mentioned in sentence 2 (who painted them, how long they were hidden). This information naturally follows the discovery of the murals.

Answer: C (after sentence 2)

Advanced Example (Paragraph Placement):

Essay about a scientist's career:

Paragraph 1: Introduces Dr. Sarah Kim and her childhood fascination with insects
Paragraph 2: Describes her groundbreaking discovery of a new species in 2019
Paragraph 3: Discusses her graduate research at Cornell University
Paragraph 4: Explains how this discovery led to her receiving the MacArthur Fellowship
Paragraph 5: Reflects on her current work inspiring young scientists

Question: For the sake of logic and coherence, Paragraph 3 should be placed:

F. where it is now
G. after Paragraph 1
H. after Paragraph 4
J. after Paragraph 5

Analysis:
Organization pattern: Biographical/chronological essay about Dr. Kim's life and career

Chronological markers:
- Paragraph 1: childhood
- Paragraph 2: 2019 discovery
- Paragraph 3: graduate research (typically early career, before major discoveries)
- Paragraph 4: "this discovery" refers to the 2019 discovery in Paragraph 2, describes its consequence
- Paragraph 5: "current work" indicates present day, conclusion

Problem: Graduate research should come before the 2019 discovery, not after it. The chronology is out of order.

Testing options:
- Where it is now (after Paragraph 2): Creates chronological problem ❌
- After Paragraph 1: Follows childhood with education—chronologically logical ✓
- After Paragraph 4: Would place graduate school after major discovery and award ❌
- After Paragraph 5: Would make graduate school the conclusion ❌

Logical order: Childhood (P1) → Education/Graduate research (P3) → 2019 Discovery (P2) → Award (P4) → Current work (P5)

Answer: G (after Paragraph 1)

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Logical placement questions test your ability to organize sentences within paragraphs or paragraphs within essays based on logical flow and connections
  • ✓For sentence placement, look for pronouns and demonstrative references (it, this, these, that) that require clear antecedents in the preceding sentence
  • ✓Transition words reveal logical relationships—therefore/as a result signal effects that must follow causes; however/in contrast signal opposing ideas
  • ✓Follow chronological order—dates, ages, life stages, and time markers must appear in temporal sequence
  • ✓Read the entire paragraph to understand its organization and flow before deciding where a sentence belongs
  • ✓For paragraph placement, identify each paragraph's function (introduction, development, conclusion) and recognize the essay's organizational pattern
  • ✓Look for dependencies—paragraphs with references like "this discovery" or "these efforts" must follow the paragraph introducing what they reference
  • ✓Common essay patterns include chronological/biographical, problem-solution, general-to-specific, cause-effect, and process description
  • ✓Test each placement option by mentally inserting the sentence/paragraph and checking whether references, chronology, and transitions work logically
  • ✓Budget 45-60 seconds for sentence placement, 60-90 seconds for paragraph placement—strong clues often make answers obvious quickly
